art direction: 10/10
Puzzles: 8/10
Music: 8/10
That pacman segment with a touchpad: 1/10

the main story is short, but there's a lot of replay value if you go for all the creature cards. As someone who generally doesn't like point and clicks a ton, this game was fun in part because it didn't have the most annoying parts of point and clicks for me. Since you're characters mostly don't (and can't) move around the screens, you don't have to constantly click just to watch them slowly crawl over, and transitions between areas is pretty fast, so you get to focus on the puzzles without spending a bunch of time walking around.

144113955.review:
Deep in the icy realms of my heart, where emotions are as frosty as the tundra winds, I, Kiba Snowpaw, the lonely Alpha male Ice Wolf, nestled into my snowy den to traverse the heartwarming journey of Botanicula. Being in the gaming world since my very first breath 36+ years ago, I have seen many games come and go, each leaving an indelible mark on my soul. Today, though, I wish to share with you a tale interwoven with drama, emotion, and resilience as I dive deep into this game that echoes a fragment of my life.

The world of Botanicula is rich with vibrancy, mirroring the colorful tapestry of emotions I've been grappling with since my teenage years. The five botanical creatures, each with their unique quirks, were reminiscent of different aspects of my being. From Mr. Lantern's glowing demeanor, which often reflected the occasional spark of hope that I felt in my most depressive moments, to Mr. Twig's multi-armed reach, akin to my many attempts to grasp happiness in a maze of toxicity.

Venturing through the game, it was almost therapeutic. Each puzzle I unlocked and every tiny creature I interacted with became symbolic of the intricate relationships and challenges I've encountered. The easter eggs were delightful surprises, much like those rare moments when the cold exterior of my world would melt away to reveal a glimmer of warmth.

While many might say this is just a game, to me, Botanicula was a story of companionship, courage, and survival - emotions I am all too familiar with. The little mushroom's ability to clone herself spoke to the masks I wear daily, hiding my true self from the cruelty of the world. Mr. Poppyhead, robust and unwavering, reminded me of those few, steadfast friends who stood by me amidst my many toxic relationships.

The soundtrack is a medley of emotions. Every tune and sound effect resonated with the depths of my being, invoking both joy and melancholy. Just as the music by DVA brought life to the game, the memories and moments of my journey found expression in the ebb and flow of these melodies.

Having played many adventure games, Botanicula stands out not just for its intricate design and gameplay, but for the emotional odyssey it offers. It's a celebration of life, friendship, and resilience. I've found solace and a reflection of my struggles within this game. The very essence of the game can be summed up in a phrase: battling darkness with the glow of hope and camaraderie.

While the game provides a rich sensory experience, the lack of replay value is something the developers could ponder upon. However, the overall storytelling, design, and music are an ode to creativity, making it a masterpiece in its genre.

Navigating the game world of Botanicula was like traversing through the layers of my life, unearthing memories, pain, and the few moments of joy. As Kiba Snowpaw, an ice wolf forever battling the cold winds of loneliness and depression, I'd highly recommend this game to those looking to lose, and find, themselves in a magical realm. 🐾🌨️🎮🖤🌌

140173889.review:
While I see a lot of people enjoy this game and posting good reviews, I can't personally recommend it. I've played other games by Amanita, and really like them. This one, however, was a chore and an annoyance to get through!

This game is all out space logic! Not that all of Amanita Design's games are the most intuitive(yet even Samorost and Machinarium are better, despite being older), but they have certainly gotten better at it after this game! Sure, you can gleam some logic here and there, but for the most part this feels like an "ADHD game", where the game design seems to be "how can we cram the most amount of randomness illogically into a couple of mouse clicks?"

There are some neat puzzles, like the water drop and spoons puzzle. But then there are other times where you use gameplay features that have not been established, and is only used once, like one where you have to not only click, but click *and hold down* the button to "charge up" a creature and make a big bubble. (Holding down the button like this having never been a thing before, and never really being a thing afterwards.) And clicking it normally makes tiny bubbles, so it looks like that's the function. Meanwhile, there's nothing to indicate you even need a bubble in the first place. This is absolutely terrible game design, and the game is filled with similar examples. It also contains pixel hunting of the kind I thought we'd got rid of in the 90s, and not just for the optional stuff, but even some 

The game is very similar to Chuchel in art style and silliness, but Chuchel has good game design: Chuchel always cleverly teaches you the mechanics of the gameplay, almost without you noticing. Which makes sense, as Chuchel was made six years later than Botanicula, so the team has learned a lot since this game.

Botanicula was also an assault on my hearing. This is probably more a preference thing than anything else, and it's not that the sound design or audio in general is bad, it's just way too much at so many points in the game. Now, I do actually have hypersensitivity to hearing, which probably adds to why this bothers me so, but I can't remember any other game ever that has had such an annoying audio design.

I could write more criticism on the story and characters, which are fine, but there are certainly some flaws there as well. But I don't feel like getting more deep with this review. I'll just mention a couple of other annoyances: A lot of hotspots you need to interact with are so close to the top or bottom of the screen that you very often activate the UI, which then has to close for you to actually interact with the actual game again and click the hotspot you wanted. And the in game map is a joke, and is so useless that it's easier to memorize the level layout than decipher how the map works with the level.

All in all, I suggest getting just about any other Amanita game than this one.

100% in about 6 infuriating hours. (Do yourself a favor and use a guide. Also, save every level, as there's no chapter select!)

140098306.review: Fun and wacky puzzles. Cute creatures and nice environmental design. Have childhood memories playing other Amanita games so Botanicula is a nice edition to the list of games that I've played from them.

139867633.review:
From the creators of Samorost and Machinarium comes Botanicula which is point and click game similar to the rest of Amanita Design's other games. The art-style, music consisting of non language vocal percussion, vocal sound effects, nature theme, interactive environment makes it signature of Amanita's game design. The lack of words except for menu interface consisting of only pictograms and "visual speech bubbles" allows for language barriers to be broken and understandable to everyone especially younger children due to the art-style and music. Some of the puzzles are frustrating to solve if you cannot wrap your head around it so don't be afraid to look up a guide if stuck.

The only replay value Botanicula provides would be creature cards to collect and achievements to collect.

Buy Botanicula during sales along with other Amanita Design's games because those are some of the most soulful and unique games of the point-and-click genre on Steam.

138462972.review:
Juego de puzzles muy original y gracioso. Lo juego a ratos porque hay momentos que me quedo bloqueado. Pero hasta la fecha ha conseguido picarme la curiosidad.

He avanzado bastante y llegando al final hay una fase de disparo muy muy dificil. La mecanica es la siguiente: solo dispones de un disparo, que una vez realizado tienes que recargar haciendo clic sobre tu esfera. A continuacion colocas el cursor sobre el enemigo y sin ningun boton dispara automaticamente directo al enemigo. Hay enemigos pequeños que eliminas con un solo disparo y otros mayores que necesitan varios. Cual es el problema? los enemigos flojos y tu esfera son diminutos y no es nada facil colocar el cursor encima, ya que ellos van avanzando hacia ti y si se acercan demasiado mueres. Y en la tercera habitacion son muchisimos. Te pones de los nervios.

Tambien en el 4º cap. te tropiezas con una superficie bastante amplia y muy laberintica. Y el mapa no ayuda mucho que digamos ya que la simbologia no es muy inteligible.

Tengo que comentar que, por lo menos para mi, el juego tiene un fallo tecnico. En ocasiones el cursor desaparece por el morro, reapareciendo en la parte superior de la pantalla. Esto dificulta bastante la resolucion de algunos puzzles, como el del gusano que ha robado el sol.
Perdon por el spoiler.

Por lo demas el juego esta bastante bien. Graficos picasianos que imagino gustaran mucho a los peques. Banda sonora bien, con sonidos muy graciosos. Al igual que los personajes, muy iconicos. El argumento bueno tambien. Sin dialogos (no precisa traduccion) ya que todo se explica con dibujos y videos. Algunos puzzles son muy faciles y el resto tampoco tienen una dificultad excesiva, aunque los hay realmente absurdos. Casi todo se soluciona haciendo clic por todas partes, buscando las piezas que son interactivas.

Lo recomiendo si te gusta el genero. 7 / 10

134682401.review:
Botanicula es un juego impresionante que cautiva por su diseño visual, su banda sonora relajante y su mundo imaginativo y lleno de vida. Desde el primer momento, el juego atrae con su belleza y creatividad.

El diseño gráfico del juego es simplemente impresionante, con detalles intrincados y un uso brillante del color. Los entornos están llenos de vida y texturas, con cada criatura y elemento del mundo diseñado con cuidado y detalle.

La banda sonora del juego es igualmente impresionante. Con una mezcla de sonidos naturales, música relajante y melodías juguetonas, la música complementa perfectamente la experiencia del juego.

Pero lo que hace que Botanicula sea realmente especial es la interacción con el mundo. Los jugadores pueden explorar cada rincón del mundo del juego y descubrir cosas nuevas en cada esquina. Los personajes son divertidos y excéntricos.

La jugabilidad es en gran parte de exploración y resolución de puzles. Los jugadores deben recolectar objetos y usarlos de maneras ingeniosas para avanzar en el juego. Los puzles son desafiantes pero no frustrantes, y siempre hay una sensación de logro al superar un obstáculo.

En general, Botanicula es un juego maravilloso que debe ser experimentado por cualquiera que busque una experiencia única y cautivadora. El diseño visual y la banda sonora son excepcionales, y el mundo del juego es una delicia para explorar. Si te gustan los juegos de aventuras y puzles, no puedes equivocarte con Botanicula.

Botanicula es una aventura "point & click" bastante original y con un acertado sentido del humor.
Sus gráficos son agradables y coloridos, y sus paisajes son variados y están repletos de personajes llenos de carisma.
La banda sonora es muy acertada, sin llegar a ser brillante, y los efectos de sonido y las voces de los personajes son excelentes, lo que los hace todavía más entrañables.
En estos dos apartados, tanto en los gráficos como en los efectos sonoros, me recuerda bastante a "Loco Roco" de PSP.
La jugabilidad es excelente por lo sencillo que resulta entender las mecánicas de juego y su fácil ejecución. En seguida te verás avanzando sin problemas en la historia.
La dificultad es muy baja. De hecho, sin necesidad de una guía, podrás pasarte el juego con todos sus logros en apenas 5 horas. Esto resta enteros al título que, aunque entretenido y muy divertido, su escasa durabilidad hará que nos sepa a poco.
En definitiva, un juego muy bueno en todos sus apartados, pero excesivamente sencillo y corto. Recomendable para los que gustan de este tipo de aventuras y para jugadores casual.

NOTA: 7/10

Been meaning to play through this one ever since Machinarium charmed me a decade ago. 
This game is all about eternal spring, and feels positively relaxing to play. Often the sound and visual design is so perfectly merged as to be truly charming. It's a neat and simple little package, and if you're going through its' paces, I think 3-5 hours should suffice. It's the sort of thing that if its sweetness and charm clicks with you, then you want to see it through because there are so many little living tidbits to mouse-over and discover. Exploration is key and all puzzles are communicated visually, so its best to push onward to their resolution, otherwise it may be easy to forget where you were or get lost (stage 5 has many screens).

Nice, low risk entertainment.

125197231.review:

[th][b] ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ [/b][/th]

[b]Don't panic in botany[/b]

With Botanicula, Amanita Design, which should no longer be an insider tip since Machinarium at the latest, presents a mixture of adventure, puzzle and search game and work of art in a somewhat strange tree world that is threatened by spider-like creatures. A team of five strange creatures face the threat and set out to save their world.
[url] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2863233805[/url]
[b]The Famous Five[/b]

I have absolutely no idea which insects or animals served as models here. I'm reminded of our five friends, um no, sorry, our heroes of a twig, a mushroom, something with a feather, maybe a beetle and some kind of hazelnut. But maybe they are something completely different. Who knows….
But exactly this motley bunch wants to survive against the parasites and plant the last seed?

The whole story is told completely without language and only with pictures. The control is also quite simple and so everything is controlled simply with the mouse in the simplest way and is therefore almost self-explanatory. [b]But despite this reduction, the game is anything but boring.[/b]

For me, the adventure, which is more like a bustling picture puzzle, is an audiovisual work of art in which many parts of the game don't even really belong to the mission and are just a gimmick. The entire world consists of scenes affecting all parts of a tree. From the roots down to the smallest leaf and the places you visit in the course of the game are actually not always really pretty or colorful and sometimes they seem rather repulsive.
Nevertheless, they are all extremely colorful and have their very own charm. In addition, there is the atmospheric music, or let's call it a collection of various sounds and noises by the band Dva, which isn't really nice either (no, not the band, I mean the music), let alone can be classified somewhere concrete.
[url] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2863233602[/url]
But that's exactly what the two band members wanted, because their music often comes from everyday sounds or self-made instruments, which all in all creates a unique and yet well-composed masterpiece.

[b]But of course an adventure also includes tasks. [/b]
The tasks usually consist of finding one or more objects and using them in other places.
Finding is less of a problem here. The question often arises as to how to find the actual solution or how to manipulate the game world in such a way that our dream team can get the required object.
Once you have found out what is helpful for progress, the only question that remains is what exactly to do with it. Drag, click or something completely different?

And this is where The Famous Five come into play again because they are always part of the puzzle solution.
Each of the five has different special abilities that sometimes even have to be combined. From time to time, however, only one of the five can pass the task and if you don't choose the right one right away and mess up the task, you get to see a funny animation and can try your luck again.
But even here, the often annoying trial and error becomes fun and not a frustrating task.

And sometimes it seems that all this is not quite optimal, but the game is still structured so logically that everything fits together in the end.
What Botanicula shines with once again are all the fantastic little mini-games, such as a kind of labyrinth that is somewhat reminiscent of the game "the buzz wire", smaller shooter sequences or races and the whole creativity behind it is absolutely fascinating.

Even if the game is different, but still uses many well-known elements, the way it is so unusual that it may be, will be or could be too strenuous for one or the other.

Nevertheless, Botanicula is a game that is definitely suitable for all ages, precisely because the presentation is more like an interactive picture book and can be discovered without any language.
One or the other riddle may be a little harder, but maybe it's only because adults often don't think of unconventional and obvious solutions.

Characters don't evolve over the course of the game. As well as.
It's a bit difficult without language and in-depth history.
Nevertheless, the game brings an atmosphere that you really rarely experience, which is certainly due to the design. The graphics themselves, in terms of design, are beyond criticism in my opinion.

Botanicula is not the big adventure, not even for the head.
The puzzles are just too transparent for that. But the special thing about it is discovering and “touching”.
Everything reacts to the movement of the mouse and sometimes you have to guess whether you have to click, drag or press to get to your destination.

Friends of the demanding combination puzzles will be absolutely underchallenged here and somehow then also with the wrong game. The solutions to many puzzles are simply too banal or even arbitrary for that.

Amanita Design is known for its comical games, but comical here means different, fun, and definitely remarkable.
And the games are always different, because these curiosities, the different and imaginative worlds with the successful interplay of graphics and soundscape impress across the board.

[b]Anyone who likes the games from Amanita Design and knows and loves the Samorost series will certainly feel at home here.[/b]

Review date: November 09, 2022

116839775.review:
Botanicula could have easily been a perfect game if only it had been advertised a bit differently. As I prize myself to be quite the hardcore adventure gamer and having come to love Amanita Design through its wonderful, rusty and melancholic Machinarium, I was expecting Botanicula to be a game in the same trend of witty puzzles and shaking emotion. 
And indeed, when it comes to emotion, Botanicula never fails to deliver. The main characters are memorable, the art style surprisingly beautiful in its simplicity - it looks as if the producers have stolen some doodles from a kindergarden drawing session and have infused those scribbles with divine breath. The result is unforgettable. Combined with the playful music (which is sometimes veeeeery close to annoying but never quite passes that borderline) this makes Botanicula one of the most expressive games ever. It is amazing how little is needed to masterfully tell a story which goes deeper then even most triple A titles. I can't thus shake a peculiar feeling, as if I'm watching a cubist piece of art and I'm not sure if I should take it as it is, or dig deeper for hidden meanings and risk ruining the actual artistic message.
When it comes to puzzles though, to understand Botanicula one must turn to the developer's website and READ THE SMALL PRINT: Botanicula is not a proper adventure game, but a point-and-click EXPLORATION game. Of course I myself, with the characteristic modern impatience, totally ignored this difference in nuance in the beginning and found myself (or rather my neurons) deeply disappointed. The game is rarely brain teasing and limits itself to encouraging spam-clicking all over the screen to discover the lush, green micro-universe. Some of the puzzles don't even make sense, or rather suggest that this botanical word has rules which rarely respect the physical world logic. Some puzzles are obviously developed with handheld touch screen devices in mind and feel kind of clunky with the mouse. 
But if you're ready to slow down, accept this wacky universe and witness it as a perpetual celebration of life over death and decay, you'll be facing one of the most artsy and good-taste games ever. So wipe the ADVENTURE game pattern from your mind and prepare to embrace a new kind of experience... Botanicula.

116342017.review:
Cheerful and whimsical puzzle-adventure. Really enjoyed this!  Well-made and well thought out point-and-click. A little group of creature friends travel together around a big tree, keeping out of the way of threatening spiders and such, going on side quests finding things and helping other creatures.  Lots of little mini-games where you often have to squeeze your brain a bit to figure out what the goal is or the solution to get there. Colourful, fun, rewards curiosity and exploration.

There's a map, which shows new areas as you explore them. Lots of achievements for all kinds of things, silly, helpful, curious, etc. - and a neat achievement overview in top screen margin. Also a useful quest/item counter. 

The group of friends travel together, sometimes dividing up different tasks in quests or difficult situations according to their particular characteristics (long, thin, flying, heavy...). But not rpg.

No platforming. A couple of the minigames in the first chapters are arcadish and timed, but most aren't. For someone like myself who has slow reflexes, gnarly hands, and very simple gear - I found that up to the last chapter there were altogether a handful of minigames I had some trouble with, and one in particular that was very tightly timed where you're being chased in a labyrinth and which I found very frustrating.  

Up to the start of the final chapter the mood of the game is quite light - a couple of cartoonish scares where paths forward are blocked by an angry spider or beetle or such, but quite low key.  Nothing unkind or cruel.  And the general tone bright and cheerful.

However, in the end of the last chapter (underwater region), the mood of the game turns a lot darker and tense and would likely be scary for smaller children. And uncomfortable for people with arachnophobia. In this final section there is also some quite difficult arcade-type gameplay requiring fast and precise clicking to get through. I am very very bad at arcade, and would never have managed this section just with my standard non-gaming mouse. Had to switch to pad mode and use touchscreen to get through it.

Saving worked fine, autosaves on exit, plus manual saves. Menu and controls are fine.  Encountered a few minor glitches couple of places, but nothing serious or gamebreaking (reloading solved all). No other issues. Worked smooth on my very basic gear, kb+m. Although as mentioned, in the arcade sections in the final chapter, I had to resort to touchscreen, as my mouseclicking wasn't fast enough.

Playtime at review is for one full playthrough, plus about halfway into a new game.

115380867.review:
If you don’t know what to expect, Amanita games are 2D point & clicks in a relaxed, imaginative setting and atmosphere with often quite whimsical characters and some light puzzling. A lot of the time you simply click on stuff and see what happens. Nature often plays a part and words like “adorable” or “cute” easily comes to mind while playing. [i]Botanicula[/i] is no different: everything is as adorable and whimsical as ever. There’s also a lot of extras to discover and activate.

The story isn’t trying for anything particularly profound or life-changing, but it doesn’t have to and gets the job done quite competently. If you are into having your mind bent and can’t have it any other way, this is probably not the game for you. Everyone else will love it.

The music is sort of a mix between Steve Reich, Meredith Monk, and Dvar in their lightest, most playful moments, and also sometimes interactive. The sound design is great and sets a perfect tone for the game. The puzzles are well integrated with the surroundings and often consists of bridging a gap, climbing something, or finding a most needed object by interacting with the environment or the NPCs, and choosing which of your characters to use—as they come with different skills.

It’s a fun game which I think could easily draw a smile from even the stiffest, most determined grumpy old fart. If you are still not liking it, then being a kid—either by heart or by design—might help. It’s a perfect fit for when you need a break, but don’t want to, or cannot, leave your computer.

Full review:
https://maskinkultur.com/2018/04/10/review-botanicula/

106175627.review:
Plucked this one from the depths of my backlog.

Having finished the game, I can't say I'm ecstatic about the experience, but I'm content with it. It's a quirky point-and-click adventure game that offers a little bit of everything: some moments are endearing, others are plain weird, others still are of comedic nature, and a handful just might be described as mildly disturbing.

Botanicula offers plenty of locations to explore, yet overall they are all quite samey. This'd be a major problem if not for the characters that populate them, because somehow, despite not having any dialogues to offer, their presence does manage to brighten things up considerably, and seeing the world's denizens living their lives is actually pretty neat.

Released in 2012, Botanicula certainly feels dated by now, but not horribly so. It took me about 4 hours to beat the game. Overall, it's a chill experience that has no dizzying highs to offer, but it's a decent ride, and ultimately I'm glad that I've finally given it a go.

What a quirky, fun-filled little game this is, and one I would say is a hidden gem. Very simple, easy puzzles that you won't be stuck on for very long. Each area is relatively easy to navigate and it's a lot of fun finding out what each little interactive bits for each area does. I explored and played around with everything so it took me nearly 7.5hrs to complete (also going back through for some of the achievements I missed). 
Now I must admit the one thing in this game I absolutely love are all the 'hand-made' sound effects. They're so darn adorable!! Made this game really come to life, paired along with the simple art style. I found myself constantly re-clicking on some things that made a hilarious sound.
The story is wonderful, told well through the game's actions. There's no understandable words in it (just cute mutterings), but everything is explained as you go via visual stories. I got right into it, thoroughly enjoyed it. You can tell this game was made with a lot of love.

Definitely a game for the young and old. If you enjoy the simpler types of games, I recommend giving this one a go. My 4 year old girl found this game amusing, and although she doesn't quite understand the purpose, she sure had fun clicking on everything to see what would happen. Worth the dollars to hear the kids laugh and giggle too!

A truly beautiful and breathtaking point and click from Amanita Design. 

This one is one of their longer and more atmospheric titles, kind of similar to Machinarium, although this one is about plants and natural life, more than robots and stuff like that. It's a really nice parallel to Machinarium in my opinion. Both took me around 4 hours to complete and have big worlds to explore. I think if you've enjoyed Machinarium you'd enjoy this (and if you haven't enjoyed either yet - get on it!)

It's a lot of fun and has a lot of heart. It's a very cute game without being over the top cutesy at all. The puzzles in it ride a nice difficulty curve too, where they're not too easy to figure out, but not mind-bendingly hard either. So there's a lot of substance here.

I should also mention the music and visuals - both are just fantastic, with tunes that remind you of relaxing in the garden, and levels full of unearthly bioluminescent glows. It's worth experiencing.

If you're curious, I would give it a shot - I think it's honestly one of the best games of its genre.

97580090.review:
This is your typical Amanita fare: intuitive story and gameplay (click on all the things!) with no actual dialog or text. The characters are cute and emotive despite their simple art. The environments give a great sense of busied microscopic ecology. The music is calming, quirky and catchy. Of course, everything is mixed with a few minor hallucinogens.

If you like the other Amanita games, you'll like this one.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Adorable
+Family-friendly
+Casual, save anywhere, no deaths
+Includes a map
+Double-click to transition faster

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~I didn't personally have any issues with pixel hunting or really frustrating puzzles (I'm looking at you, Machinarium board game). There were two puzzles I couldn't figure out the logic for, so I just brute forced them.

~Achievements can be missed, but can be picked back up quickly on a second playthrough with a guide.

~3-5 hours of play, which is Amanita's usual ratio of time vs money. You may want to wait for a sale.

~If you're interested in it, the OST on Steam has two more tracks and is cheaper than the one on the artist's bandcamp site. Further, you're less likely to see a sale on the bandcamp one.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Can't pause the game.
-Top and bottom menus are easy to accidentally click on.

89733249.review:
Botanicula, another point 'n' click game from Amanita Design, is set in a very atmospheric world of plants. It is more an interactive fairy tale than a game. The game is a work of art, captivating with both image and sound. Graphics in Botanicula is characterized by great attention to detail and a masterful selection of pastel colors. The shape and appearance of each encountered character impress with its charm. The sound design by the Czech band DVA is just as phenomenal as the graphics (or even better!). The sounds made by individual elements of the environment, as well as the musical pieces that we will listen to while playing, perfectly match all the situations in which they appear and create the atmosphere. The music DVA created for this project is spectacular, they call it a combination of kitchen beatbox and freak-folk. It's definitely in my top 10 game music soundtracks!

MASTERPIECE! Definitely try it!

88262473.review:
Botanicula is an excellent, short little adventure with a lot of charm and love put into it. I dismissed it originally cause it seemed a bit too simple and sappy compared to other Amanita games but it turned out to be quite the opposite.
At the core Botanicula is like a little fairy tale. You control a group of tiny creatures of varied build and purpose and explore a giant living tree and meet the other living things that inhabit it until spider like creatures start sucking out life and chasing you down. So now you set out on a journey to save your habitat from this menace. It's very simple but told well and with a surprising amount of depth. They even created a coherent little mythology and a prophecy that you follow without using a single word.
The exploration part of the game is extremely well fleshed out to a point where I'd consider it the most fun part of the game. Just going around and clicking on everything and seeing what happens is fun, I loved meeting new things and seeing what they do and how they tie into this whole ecosystem the game slowly builds up. The sound design supports it as well cause everything you do and everything you meet has its own voice that often ties into the background music. 

When it comes to gameplay there's very little challenge. I think the intention was to engage you in this adventure without necessarily making the player sit on one screen and bust their brains to figure out the solution to puzzles. As such you'll usually be able to recognize solutions at a glance and always have an idea of what you need to do. There are a few exceptions cause navigation can get a bit convoluted and some interactions are not very intuitive but it was never bad enough to impede my progress in any real way.

Overall it's a very easy recommendation, the game is well worth the price but if you're not sure it's your thing I hope you at least check it out on sale.

79068548.review:
A friend gifted me with Botanicula when I joined Steam, and I played it off and on for about a week before I finished it.  I found the animation enthralling and adorable, and I loved the joy the heroes took when they were jumping from branch to branch.  

I enjoyed the story of the game; I have always loved stories of heroes trying to defeat evil and going on heroic quests.  And the idea of trying to save the seed of a magical tree from a villain especially appealed to the nature-loving part of me.  I liked how they were able to communicate the story without words, making it open for anyone to play, no matter their native language.  

I found some of the mini-games difficult enough that I had to seek out help from others who have played this game; I wish there were hints if you get stuck.  I missed a number of achievements; I wish they were easier to find.  I liked how you can't die or do the wrong thing; once I figured that out, it became much less stressful.

The last level was darker than I expected, but that was okay; heroes on epic quests need to face impossible odds once in a while.  However, part of it was difficult enough I had to watch some walkthroughs of it on YouTube.  I don't mind it being so hard, I just wish there had been a few clues at times.  

I would recommend this game to everyone who enjoys puzzle games and adventure stories.

78339915.review:
Botanicula flourishes in imaginative creativity through humorously designed plant organisms that grow with the point-and-click adventure, although the simple quest for quelling the infestation of parasites prevents any replay value whatsoever.

WHAT I LIKED:
+ "So a Physalis, a mushroom, a poppy seed, a twig and a feather walk into a bar...". Much like Amanita Design's previous work, the strength of its environmental adventure is through its zany non-verbal characters, This includes the five protagonists, whom are trying to save the last seed of their home tree from parasitic creatures, and the plethora of fauna they encounter along the way. Each one entirely interactable, either granting the player a valuable item to be used later or simply just to provide some weird nonsensical humour. It supplies the point-and-click quest with an abundance of charm, character and charisma that differentiates itself from other similar titles.
+ A luscious tree brought to life. Amanita's art direction for Botanicula settles for the simplistic, embodying the type of style that was prevalent within browser games of the late noughties, but retains its aesthetic throughout. Considering it was created on Adobe Flash, the design work really shines through. Clear prompts are given as to which direction the botanical protagonists can travel in. Items are importance are highlighted for the player to collect. The wildlife, both in the background and foreground, match the environment that they reside in. Botanicula truly felt like an ecosystem of its own.
+ Hum-hum-hummm-hum. Much of the charm comes from the sound editing and score. With no verbal communication, the characters communicate through mumbles and whistles, which in turn generates a thought bubble for the player to visualise. Hearing a "Yee-hoo" will indicate a positive outcome, and these signals help enhance that required accessibility for younger players.

WHAT I DISLIKED:
- As mentioned, Botanicula plays well for the younger demographic. Adults and/or players who are familiar with point-and-click adventures will find this game far too easy. The puzzles and environmental obstacles on offer could easily be accomplished without a hesitation. Guiding a star through a maze whilst it's being chased by a worm? Simple. Racing ladybugs around a leaf? Done. The lack of challenges makes Botanicula a breeze to complete, with only the familiarisation of each level being the trickiest aspect (although a map is accessible...).
- Save the home tree again? Doubtful. Only a select few point-and-click adventures have replay value, unfortunately Botanicula has none. Once the botanical beings have banished the parasites for good, the game simply ends and can be played again from the start. No chapter select. Easter Eggs can be unlocked if the player interacts with a certain number of creatures, but the reward for doing such a task seems fruitless.

VERDICT:
6/10 botanical organisms

Great point-and-click puzzle game. Wonderfully done!

Quirky art style, funny game mechanics and sound effects, and richly varied types of puzzle designs to solve. Mixed in with a weird and fascinating story, all make this one of the most unique game experiences you'll find. 

I played this with my 7-year old niece over 4-5 sessions. She loved the characters and artwork while I loved the puzzles. Many of the puzzles were easy enough for her to figure out. 72673225.review: I was initially a bit cool on this game since the art style was so different from [i]Machinarium[/i], but I've grown to appreciate [i]Botanicula[/i] more as time has gone on. For a start there are lots of memorable locations I enjoyed, like the chestnut city, the underwater section, or simply certain individual screens, like the one where it zooms out on the edge of the weird tree complex where our characters live and we see an ancient tortoise just chilling in the background. As always the music and sound direction are top notch and contribute a lot to the atmosphere. Also, there is a real existential threat in [i]Botanicula[/i] that wasn't really present in [i]Machinarium[/i] and I think the game benefits from these raised stakes. Add a lot of secrets and funny little moments and you've got a bizarre, but enjoyable experience.

72512656.review:
The 1st game (out of 138) to be picked at random as part of a personal challenge to clean out my entire Steam backlog: Botanicula. Below are some brief points on which I (tend to) decide if I buy a game or not.

Core experience: Non-verbal linear story.
Core mechanic: Point-and-click with puzzle elements.
Core vibe: Laid-back.
Duration: Less than 4 hours.
Replay value: (Aside from missed collectibles) None.

Additional thoughts: 
The art and music are in sync with each other. Both adding to a frisky, but light, experience. The puzzles are easy in a way that it doesn't distract from the adventure it's trying to tell. Although, there certainly are puzzles, albeit few, that force you to stop and think.

My conclusion: 
I enjoyed the light-hearted spirit of Botanicula for 1 playthrough and it contributed to wanting to know if Amanita Design has more games like this.

72510552.review:
This is a point and click adventure game. If that's not your thing, this isn't for you.

You explore nature in a series of 2D mazes to solve silly puzzles and find hidden objects. The game is very casual and intended to be a relaxing experience. The art style is kid-friendly and the music/sound effects give it a humorous and chill vibe.

Overall it's bizarre but enjoyable. It's not terribly long, but it's priced reasonable and plays smoothly. There's some replay value if you want to hunt for achievements, it's a bit like digital bug collecting and some of them are well hidden.

If you need high speed action and big explosions this isn't the game for you, but then again you probably weren't looking at this anyway. For what it's trying to be, it's done well.

71906162.review:
I have had this game in my library for a long time but I only recently just played it.

It is a short game at about 4.5 hours for me and at first my instinct is to say that $10 is too high, but then I realize I have spent $15 to see a 2 hr movie at the theater. So, in that sense it is cheaper entertainment. 

To me it felt like I was playing a pop-up book. It is very kid friendly if you play it together. There is no real explanation so you drop in and start figuring it out yourself. I started by clicking on literally everything. Then I learned some things need to be clicked repeatedly. Some of the puzzles may be too difficult for a young child on their own (like younger than 10). Teens should be okay. Your plant world is being attacked by evil creepy crawlies and you have to work your way to safety. There are lots of cutesy characters and animations.

There are some parts that you have to be able to observe patterns of events but things don't necessarily repeat in an expected fashion of absolute pattern repetition. It's kind of a mixed bag. What I mean is, say in a game you have 4 doors. You go into door 1, and it takes you to a sunset. You go into door 2, and it takes you to a forest. When you go back to door 1, it may not take you back to the sunset. The pattern of where you go isn't necessarily absolute on which door you enter. There was one part like that (not with doors). That's why I think little kids might have trouble figuring out the mechanics at the more difficult parts. It does require a little bit of creativity to click and explore and ponder how, or if, you can use various objects and characters to your advantage.

I liked it and found it very relaxing to play after work. 

I'm not sure I completely understood the story and what happened, but I know I won! I recommend it if you like casual semi-puzzle games. I say semi-puzzle because a portion of the gameplay is discovery by clicking to see what happens.

69703131.review:
As expected from Amanita, a delightful and sometimes absurd game. There's some slightly head-scratching puzzles - it's not always obvious what the cause/effect is, so a little brute forcing is necessary, but mostly it flows well and the player is frequently rewarded for exploratory clicks and even repeated clicks. 

The narrative is quite interesting, especially considering there is no text and it even avoids using symbols or signs as much as possible. Having completed it, I'm now left wondering if it's a time loop or a frame story, or just as straight-forward as it might seem. Not bad for a game featuring nonverbal protagonists of unclear taxonomy.

Accessibility notes: Sound not necessary, although audio cues can be helpful confirmation of success. No text - all information is conveyed visually. Though much of the game is green on green, it's also gently outlined in white, so may still be playable by colorblind folks. Controls are very simply - point and click with a mouse. Very rarely reflexes are required, but there are a few spots. They do not require very fast reflexes, but some careful timing.

68714733.review:
[h1]A bug's life[/h1]

[b]Botanicula[/b] tells a rather familiar [i]home-no-safe-so-migrate-to-find-new-home[/i] -story from the point of view of five bugs. These bugs, as most of creatures in this point-and-click adventure, are charmingly cute and come straight from the artists' imagination. No dialog or written text is required, as you'd expect from the developers at [b]Amanita Designs[/b]. They are masters of storytelling, using only gibberish mumbling and occasional symbols to replace the dialogue. This, the visual artwork and the soundtrack really create an atmosphere, making the world of Botanicula feel alive and real.

I really wanted to give the game a thumbs-up but it's only 3-4 hours long, depending on the player's puzzle-solving skills. This isn't a problem itself but the game just is not... fun. I'm sure people that have children to play the game with might disagree with me. That being said, I probably do not fit the game's target audience so take this review lightly.

68706649.review: Botanicula is a wonderful point and click adventure in which you navigate a tiny world full of charming characters to save your home from . . . a spooky dust mote? Botanicula is beautiful, charming, and has a great soundtrack. I strongly recommend it!

68648283.review:
Botanicula is an adventure of the point-and-click subgenre with a minimal amount of hidden-itemism and a strong, driven storyline.

Beating the game is not very challenging, which makes it appropriate for children, even young children (though they may need assistance in places). Despite the difficulty, I found it enjoyable even for hardcore puzzle-enthusiasts like myself. The graphics, music, and story are adorable and very engaging, and it's a great game you can play casually while relaxing as it requires no keyboard input.

It is challenging to find all of the events in the game. I did manage to do it after about eight passes through the game (I'm a completionist), but it took a lot of effort. Still, I enjoyed the discovery process and found it entertaining even after several playthroughs.

It's a great game with wide appeal, though some of the events could be a little more straightforward and harder puzzle options would have been appreciated. Odds are you'll like it. I give it 8/10.

64943348.review:
Botanicula is a point and click adventure/puzzle game where you help a group of "plants" on a journey to transport a very important glowing seed. This game stands out from other point and click adventures due to its art style of which the trailers and store page pictures give you a good idea.

The game has a very quirky-silly style and sense of humor. Expect to find references to rocket ships and aliens, for pictures of the creators to pop up, for creatures to be flung off screen with a *boing* sound effect. If you like that sort of thing, this game does it well. The art is unique and gives the game a whimsical vibe. All positives, again, if you like that sort of thing.

But the game has some serious flaws. The game can be hard to navigate at times. Some levels have a maze like construction and you can get lost or forget where things are despite a map. The level layout just isn't very intuitive. And while most puzzles are make enough sense, some don't seem to follow logic much, 

Also, and this will be a big problem for a lot of people, there is no story. You get cutscenes of wordless story telling, of some bad spider things going around doing bad things, and about some good glowing seed from the heavens... but that is it. You learn nothing about the group of creatures you play, nothing about the various societies and people you interact with, nothing about the bad spiders or glowy seed... just nothing. 

In the end though I can recommend this game for its style. If you look at the pictures and think this game is for you, play it, you won't regret it. But if you look at the pictures and are hesitant, give it a pass because the gameplay is adequate and there is no story.

64865508.review: A small lovely amazing fun game! Truly joyful!

64786146.review:
A wordless, casual, family-friendly P&C. Story is a little cryptic: guide 5 bug friends through a strange bug world to, uh, save a light-tree from dark-bugs? Everything moves along pretty well if you just go with it.

Great audio. Usually lighthearted, though a lot of tracks (like characters) feature a "gibberish"-speak thing that might annoy some. Really nefarious music plays when the dark-bugs are around, does a great job conveying a creepy mood.

Playtime varies quite a bit -- some report as little as 2h, took me 7h to 100% it.

If you're looking for more insect-driven P&C fun, check out [u][url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198014473461/recommended/739190/]AntVentor[/url][/u] -- different dev, different sort of world, shorter but also cheaper.

[quote]For more puzzle game reviews, news & everything puzzle-related, follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/25928931-Puzzle-Lovers/]Puzzle Lovers[/url] & check out our [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/puzzlelovers]Steam group[/url].[/quote]

Botanicula is a short game, but it's a lot of fun and it's satisfying to play.  I really like the art design, the whole game is rather cute and charming!  During the game you basically click on things to interact with them.  There is some light environmental puzzle solving, but nothing that poses much of a challenge.  Over the course of the game you will collect objects which are given to various characters who reward you with items needed to advance.  

There are 6 levels, each is pretty short, but there are dozens of insects that can be interacted with, usually with a simple mouse click.  I know what you're thinking, "clicking stuff is boring".  I'd usually agree, but the animations and discovery of the hidden bugs is enjoyable.  Clicking on a bug may cause it to hide behind a leaf, clicking the leaf will cause the bug to move again.  Sometimes you do have to interact with several objects in order for something to happen, but your curiosity is rewarded with achievements and more cute bugs.

62526609.review:
I’m going to be honest – this was not my thing, at all. Of course that doesn’t mean it’s not good, it just means it’s not for me. I’ll try to explain why.

I don’t mind the abstractness of it all, but the interactivity (or lack thereof) is what bothers me. You start out just randomly clicking some bulbs and then suddenly a weird arachnid-looking creature comes over and starts poking things. First of all, not going to lie, the creature itself was a little bit unsettling. Then my instincts scream at me “click on it! click on it!” so I do, but nothing happens. The rest of the (very little) time I spent on Botanicula, felt like watching a weird fairytale film while on drugs. I’ve never been on drugs, but I’m sure it looks and feels exactly like this.

So I don’t know what the goal of the game is, what I’m supposed to do or when I’m supposed to click and on what, and that frustrates me a lot. I like being in control and this game takes that away. The music adds to that “on edge” feeling the game gives you. Again, that is probably perfect for some or even many people, and if you are like that, I’d recommend this game as it is overwhelmingly surprising and weird. It’s just REALLY not my thing.

61938907.review: Botanicula, desarrollado por Amanita Design, es de esos juegos independientes "point & click" de los que te enamoras nada más empezar. A pesar de ser un título corto, alrededor de 3 horas, su delirante pero bello universo te empujará a querer saber más de él. En nuestro periplo, acompañando a nuestro grupo de personajes para evitar el mal de las arañas que se extiende por la vida del gran árbol, nos toparemos con alocados y entrañables habitantes a los que ayudaremos en sus delirantes situaciones de dificultad con sencillos pero gratificantes rompecabezas. Muchas veces no es tanto resolver un entuerto como experimentar con las diferentes posibilidades y el entorno para dar de si divertidos resultados. Su apartado artístico surrealista y sencillo casa perfectamente con la inocencia con la que se tratan las situaciones en el juego, como si de la mente de un niño se tratara. A ello hay que sumar un apartado sonoro precioso donde los simpáticos sonidos del entorno y los personajes se ven acompañados por una impecable banda sonora muy armónica. Es de esos juegos que con el tiempo apetece dar otra vuelta para pasar un rato agradable y lleno de humor. Muy recomendable.

Botanicula is a beautiful, relaxing and charmingly funny point-and-click puzzle game. Although all the protagonists and their adversaries (there are over 120 different kinds ! ) are weird but lovable microscopic fantasy creatures and there is no spoken or written text in Botanicula, the story makes total sense. It takes only a little while to get into the right mindset, but after you figured out the logic of this game world, all puzzles are totally doable - although some are definitively more difficult than others. The graphics and soundeffects are also fantastic(al) and greatly contribute to the quality and atmosphere of the game.

If you liked Machinarium, Samarost or Chuchel you will probably also love Botanicula.

60477011.review: Lovely and moderately challenging puzzle game. Graphics never disappoint, and the story line is solid. 60341971.review:
Curioso, bonito y divertido.

Ya lo he dicho antes y lo diré nuevamente: "la gente de Amanita Design no defrauda". Este era uno de los pocos juegos de ellos que me faltaba por probar, y al igual que como me ha pasado con todos, me ha encantado.

Al igual que algunos de sus otras sagas, Botanicula es un juego que mezcla una especie de "point & click" con "puzzles". La idea es ir interactuando con todo lo que te dé curiosidad y utilizar tu intuición para ir resolviendo los problemas que se te presentan. Su gameplay es sencillo y muy intuitivo. Su apartado gráfico es, como siempre, simple pero detallado en cantidades iguales, y con una creatividad desbordante. La banda sonora no es la gran cosa pero va muy acorde al apartado visual, y los efectos sonoros de los personas y el ambiente también.

Pros:
- Buen diseño artístico.
- Ambientación muy carismática y única.
- Banda sonora decente.
- Gameplay sencillo.

Contras:
- En teoría ninguno, excepto quizás que el juego realmente es corto y carece de una real rejugabilidad (a menos que desees tener todos los logros), lo cual a algunas personas puedes dejarle un "gusto a poco".

Conclusión:
El juego es corto, intuitivo, divertido y carismático, como todos los juegos de Amanita Design. Si te gustan los juegos de "point and click", o los juegos de "puzzles" basados en el uso de la intuición, te recomiendo este juego al 100%.

Nota:
8/10

55794576.review: As I enjoyed Amanita Design's previous work titled "Machinarium" and with people giving high praise to Botanicula, I decided to give it a try. Sadly, I felt that the gameplay was pretty lacklustre though it had pretty visuals. I've always been a fan of storytelling told in the absence of dialogue which made for an artistic narrative however, compared to machinarium, I felt that there wasn't much to the story to make it relatable to the player and its simplicity made it seem like it was more aimed towards the younger demographic of kids. With regards to gameplay, I thought that more could've been done to add a more intricate design to the puzzle-solving aspect but from what I remember, the solutions mostly involved mindless clicking on a bunch of interactive elements in the environment.

A cute, fairly relaxing game to pass some time or to chill for a bit. It's a pick up and go game, with everything done via clicking or mouse-overs. There is no dialogue. The little denizens speak a sort of gibberish but are very expressive nonetheless. Quest goals expressed via images and the only text is found on the menu options. This makes the game highly accessible regardless of someone's natural language. 

As with many point and click style games, there is some repetition of moving back and forth through the same few screens but it's not severe. At its base, it's a point and click game with some object location, getting what you want by clicking, hovering, mousing over, etc. I have found myself stumped at a couple points, not sure what I'm supposed to do when out of ideas of what to toy with on the screen. Ultimately, click everything, click it several times, and see what happens. 

The graphics are soft and easy on the eyes, adding to the sort of petri dish atmosphere, or the inside of a tree branch. A good game for a moment of relaxation or casual play.

This, along with Limbo, is what made me realize how special indie games can be. It has it's flaws, and it may not be for everyone. But it's relatively short (maybe 3 hours tops without looking for secrets/collectables) and sometimes it's easy to get lost (i.e. the little ball people village) but none of it overshadowed the sweet, charming, and eclectic adventure. 52096789.review:
There are big studios like Ubisoft and EA, pouring a lot of money and manpower into making games with shaders and VSync and visually stunning graphics, to deliver a good game. And then there are groups like Amanita, with a bunch of people with ideas, with cartoonish drawings and weird characters, to deliver an amazing game. 

Botanicula is like getting lost in a jungle while on LSD. A mushroom, a stick, a poppy, an onion, and a feather stuck to a seed is the best way I can describe the characters, and the entire gameplay feels like a trippy ride. It's elegant and simple, yet an amazing game at it. Including the little silly things that you can do by interacting with the environment, especially for achievements, this small little game delivers just as much as any other game does, even more. Visuals are beautiful, the soundtrack is cute, and controls are basically point-and-click. Even when not on sale, it is well worth the money if you love the little things in life.

A bit obtuse and it runs out of gameplay ideas half-way through its already short (around 3 hours) length, but it's an overall pleasant experience. The visuals are a mixed bag, often looking stupidly cute and quirky and other times crossing over to the "made in MS Paint" camp. The sound, on the other hand, is great; the soundtrack is fantastic and a lot of the sound effects are outright mouth sounds, which add a familiar kind of charm.

Despite its gameplay problems, I recommend it, because it's not a bad way to kill 3 hours. There is enough polish to make the game work and the whole thing oozes with love and care from the part of the developers. Ten bucks is too steep a price, but it's a good grab during a sale.

48125140.review:
Botanicula is a beautiful, soothing children's story set in an alien world of plant and insect people. The tree of life is being invaded by leeching spider monsters and you must go on an adventure to save your friends and grow a new tree. A story told with child-like wonder through charming art, point-and-click puzzles and quirky music all without words! 

Botanicula has a folksy, weird-but-heartfelt atmosphere where you will drink psychedelic wine, listen to wordless folk tales, watch puppet shows, ride inside a yellow submarine creature's head, and find miniature ostriches to run inside wheels and power the propeller that lifts a village of nut people out of harm's way. It reminds me of playing with seed propellers, nuts and rocks as a kid and imagining tiny people. A joy to play.

48079654.review:
After one of the worst years of my life I discovered this game as part of the Amanita bundle.
Such a cute, feel good little game. The detail and originality of the game world just drew me in immediately and the sound design is adorable.

43616071.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/207690/Botanicula/]Botanicula[/url] lets you lead a band of merry insects on an giddy adventure through a minuscule world that oscillates between frivolously cute and mildly vexatious.[/h1]

It will be arduous not to sound bitter when everyone else is calling this title charming and adorable, and maybe it is and I just missed it, but compared to other excellent Amanita games this one left me feeling tepid at best.

Each member of your insectile crew has unique properties that make them useful at some point. Unfortunately, their different characteristics are rarely used jointly or even in a reliably predictable manner. It is mostly a matter of picking the right one for the job, often trying out each one anyway to observe their silly antics, but there's hardly any cooperation to make interactions rewarding.

Most puzzles are simple point and click fare, except in rare situations where items must be dragged or pushed. These obscure control exceptions feel moderately awkward. My sheep got stuck in one scene and no amount of clicking or dragging or swearing would fix the problem until I exited the area and reloaded. Controlling my character in the underwater swimming bit also felt weirdly unnatural.

The flat representation of the scenery somehow makes it is easy to get lost, despite the inclusion of a self-revealing map that proves almost entirely useless. I found the scenes lacked connection at times.

The game trades the textured earthy look of other Amanita games for flat pastel shaded artwork with white outlines. The game's art direction simply did not resonate with me at all compared to the amazingly detailed microcosms of Machinarium and Samorost.

The game renders all its goofy environments and fast-paced cutscenes over a tiny portion of a standard PC monitor. Even at max settings, there is a disconcertingly thick black border around all sides of the screen, and no option to scale up the image.

Collect creature cards by interacting with the world and its myriad of insect-like characters. Earn a few tiny animated rewards at the end of the game based on your collection's completion level.

At times aurally brilliant, at times annoying, the audio is a bit of a mixed bag. Some of the songs are incredibly beautiful while others are beyond grating.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
[list]
[*] Imaginative design still procures glimpses of the genius of other Amanita titles
[*] Silly humour and charming critters
[*] Tons of little things to try and discover
[*] Audio is both a hit and a miss
[/list]

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[list]
[*] Art style and execution way below other Amanita titles
[*] Black borders, does not use full screen space
[*] Final chapter is pitch black for the most part
[*] End action sequence and frantic clicking feels out of place
[*] Confusing and useless map
[*] Flash engine is showing its age poorly
[*] Audio is both a hit and a miss
[*] Occasionally awkward character controls
[/list]

I reluctantly bought this one on a sale after years of hesitation, thinking I might like it anyway despite my first impressions since I first became aware of this game. I hoped to be delighted and surprised but the game's usurped charm did not warm my thick black heart. Now I need to go back to Machinarium and Samorost, which I highly recommend instead.

43557085.review:
This game is adorable.

Your tree has been attacked by spiders, who are sucking the sap out in a vampiric fashion!  Nothing can be done to save your beautiful tree.  However, the last acorn, the last hope for new life for your home, has been entrusted to your care.  You must traverse the length of your dying home, from the tall boughs, and down the length of the trunk.  You must guard the acorn on a perilous journey, fraught with danger and mystery in order to find a suitable location for its planting.  Along the way, you will have to dodge the evil spiders and learn the mysteries of your dying home.

You control a group of four heroes of the forest.  A stick, a nut, a seed, and a mushroom.  This is a classic puzzle adventure game, where you move from frame to frame and solve puzzles.  Collecting an item in frame A, using it later in frame E for instance.  Each of our heroes of the wood has a unique ability, and all will be used to solve the puzzles that will get your acorn to its new home.

The graphics are unique, the sounds are cute, the music is fun.  Just something about the "puzzle solved" music makes your heart soar.  The puzzles range from simplistic to quite complicated.

I whole-heartedly recommend this game, especially if you have young children

41927478.review:
"Botanicula", a production from the Czech Republic, is a sweet, little adventure in the world of plants.

You control a group of very tiny parts of plants, including a seed and a mushroom for example. There are five in total and together they explore six levels with all their branches, tunnels, caves and trails. They go to save their world from some sort of hostile black spiders sucking the life out of plants. In order to do that, they need to solve puzzles and find a variety of items along the way.

It is a very universal game. There is practically no text outside of the menu, not even some text explaing what you should do, how the game works or what characters say. But the best thing is: Everything comes clear quite quickly.
In the beginning it might be confusing, especially with those level structures, but you'll get the picture very soon by just trying out and exploring. And you will not lose your current tasks out of sight since they are displayed in a certain corner of the screen.

As for gameplay, you will mostly use your mouse, the game's controlled pretty much like a point & click game. It's easy to learn.
Also, you cannot die or read "Game over" ever. So failure is not a big deal if you're figuring out the solution of a puzzle or face aggressive creatures.

The graphics and music are great. They are not grand or perfectly created but it is a joy looking at the worlds and the weird, funny and/or cute creatures. The music fits well to the world you're in it. In character designs, music, voice work and even humour, "Botanicula" reminds me a little bit of the modern "Rayman" games.

Fine extras are the many achievements (whenever you take your time to explore the creatures you find a bit longer and whenever you finish bigger tasks like finishing levels) and Steam trading cards.

I recommend "Botanicula" strongly if you like some relaxing but also a bit challenging game with lovely, nature-filled colours and lots of little puzzles.

41780542.review:
Botanicula is a rather unique point-and-click game by Amanita Design, a Czech developer with several award winning games.

The plot of the game follows a group of five small creatures that live on a huge tree. One day, this tree starts being attacked by some parasites that drain it (and its inhabitants) of life, killing everything in their path. It's up to this group of friends to save the last seed of the tree, and protect it from the parasites. Along the way you'll come across many different creatures that also live in the tree, and you can interact with almost everything; even when in some cases it's not necessary to move forward the plot, you can still watch a fun little scene.

The gameplay is pretty simple. Like I already mentioned, it's a point-and-click game, meaning you'll be exploring different screens and solving puzzles by looking for different objects and such. The game itself is divided into 6 chapters, and in each of the chapters you need to collect a certain number of items before proceeding to the next one. Said objects are scattered across the level, and in most cases you need to solve a puzzle before obtaining them, but I wouldn't say it's very difficult. Not that it's something bad, since this is a game that anybody can play, from small children to adults.

The art style is very unique, and it's hard for me to actually describe it, but I'd say it fits the game pretty well, as all the different characters and environments have their own quirks to them. The soundtrack is also pretty good, but once again, it's hard for me to give an accurate description.

Overall, Botanicula is a fairly enjoyable game, I recommend it.

Nice little 6hr game, but not really worth it at full price.
Good for those who like to spend a few hours idly clicking around, looking for cute animations.

Pros:
- No technical difficulties.
- Good soundtrack and interesting art.
- Lots of unexpected bonus animations which are unrelated to the plot. These can be triggered by the player, some are simple to find, others require a more complex clicking order.
- There are plenty of guides out there to help you through if you get stuck.
- Easy and fun achievements, which trigger after the player finds hidden in-game animations.

Cons:

This game is a small, charming little point & click game that is a great way to kill a few hours. Some of the puzzles can be a little frustrating, relying less on puzzle solving and skill, and more on just shaking your mouse around on the screen a bunch of times until you complete them. However, these are far and few in between, so it shouldn't be a major annoyance, just a small nitpick. 

A few more of the drawbacks include: the game being too short, (you can finish it in one sitting if you so pleased), and the story isn't really deep and intricate. Though, overlooking these problems is easy as you dive deeper into the beautiful style, and the (sometimes) funny and (for lack of a better word) adorable animations.

One of my favorite things to do in this game seek out, and collect all of the 'animated cards'. The characters are lovable, even without the use of words; the art style and music are beautiful and well executed. I could listen to the Botanicula soundtrack for hours. 

Overall, yes, this is worth the ten dollars. Just don't come in expecting to get a riveting story and a long game.

Wow. This is not what I expected. It is [i]much[/i] better.
(The trailer is cute and features the actual game screens and models - but it looks like one big race. In truth, this is not a game that makes [i]you[/i] run. All you do is click things and watch what happens.)

More than anything else, this is a happy game. Things turn dicey towards the end, but fear not. This entire experience has made me smile and chuckle and laugh and just generally feel good about weird little insects and heroic seeds.
I started playing, immediately drawn in by the adorable protagonists and the music and sounds (especially the way our guys cheer when they achieve something!) ... and did not stop for hours, until I had almost reached the end.

It's a game of exploration and puzzles and trying random things for fun or progress.
A lot of the puzzles follow intuition, but some feel more unlikely than others. And that's fine: just click and push and pull anything that can be touched.
I eventually had to consult a cheat sheet because I was stuck and wanted to avoid spoiling this for myself with needless frustration. (Something I thought could only be clicked turned out to be pull-able.)

Aside from aiding our heroes on their important quest, the goal here appears to consist in collecting as many creature cards as possible. I missed about nine, or so. I will (mostly) enjoy replaying this sweet and surreal game to grab the rest!

Because, yes, this is definitely on the bizarre side.
Very little in the way of violence, though. I was an easily frightened child but except for the last level none of this would have caused me upset.

Happy, hilarious, strange -  I love Botanicula.

40182023.review:
Botanicula is a wonderous game. 
Not only is it an elegiac fable against the forces of entropy (or just plain ol' good vs evil/life vs death) but it's quirky and cute and utterly gorgeous to experience.
The art work is beautifully rendered with a soft glow to it that makes the game feel almost dreamlike. The seeds you control as well as the myriad strange creatures you encounter all have distinct and unique personalities that burst through their designs. 
The audio is truly delightful, with sharp changes in sound as you enter new areas, and not to mention the amusing noises you will hear upon interacting in various ways.

The gameplay itself is fluid and smooth, the game works very well as a point n click adventure and the animations integrate seamlessly with the movement of the mouse. The puzzles themselves are not particularly difficult but do show some measure of increasing difficulty and near the end require you to recall a fair amount of information from the interconnected areas in order to succesfully solve them. They do also allow for multiple puzzles to be worked upon at once, which gives the player some freedom to solve them in the order they choose, rather than be stuck on one and stop playing in frustration.

Highly, highly recommend this game. Well worth the money despite it's shortness. Whether you purchase to play with a child or just to appease the own child within.

40138518.review:
I can not decide, whichever addition was most infuriating in a point'n'click adventure of Amanita Design's commercially released titles - precise timing of the last puzzle in Samorost 2, endless marathon of tabletop / classic arcade rip-offs of Machinarium or dealing with never-ending chain of fetch quests in Botanicula (which are less of a target and more of a way to check your progress... also, an excuse to run through same screens several times)

Regardless, no matter which game you pick, you can safely bet that the "adventure" part is one thing that's fully delivered at 200% efficiency and, at least, once or twice the game will lead you to some weird places (and Botanicula in terms of "weird places" takes the freаking biscuit)
It is, somehow both, a heart-warming journey, acceptable for all ages, and the closest thing that will make your head spinning dizzy without ingesting some mind-altering substances.
Absolutely recommend this to everyone.

39696956.review:
Botanicula is a beautiful point-and-click adventure game. You take control of a band of critters that are trying to revitalize their tree home from the Zlo, who is sucking all of the life out of the tree and the other inhabitants on it.

In this adventure, you will be able to meet all sorts of different creatures; some will help you, others are not as friendly, and the rest are just very interesting to watch and see what they do. There's quite a bit you can click on and check out what they do and what they can do for you. Each character in the group you control each will help you along your path one way or another.

The visual is very appealing and nice to look at. The creatures range from near exact models of real-life animals to other made up critters. There are also a few cameo appearances in the art form of Botanicula. The scenery in the game also looks great. The music that was made for the game is creatively put together through the help of many of the creatures in the game. It's very light-hearted and playful music throughout this game.

The point-and-click part of this game is the sole way to navigate the game and can get boring at times (especially when you're first playing the game), but it's mostly about the journey and the puzzles that you'll solve along the way.

If you already own it and you haven't played it, it's definitely worth a try. If you want to buy it, pick this up on sale, it's a nice game to play when you've got time to kill and want to relax.

Very endearing and dream-like – when you don’t know what it is, but somehow intuitively know, how it works.

Man, I think this is my game of 2017. It's so good. It's a nice relaxing point and click adventure, it has lots of little mini-games and is an utter joy from start to finish. That's not to say it's not hard, it's damn challenging at points. But it strikes the perfect balance of being accessable to pretty much everyone but not being an easy game. What's more it's an incredibly pretty game with a good soundtrack and a really decent story. The rewards you get from exploring the levels and clicking on random things and discovering all the little creatures that live in this thriving landscape. You can tell the creator put their heart and soul into this and I look forward to playing it again to get the creatures I missed the first time round. (14, grumble)  I don't often give positive reviews, particularly not ones without a caveat, it's not your huge sprawling action-adventure but if you want a game that is relaxing and you can waste a few hours away on, I highly recommend this. 

Out of the games I've played revently, this is the first one I can say is absolutely worth the price, and I look forward to playing more by these developers.

36561878.review:
Um...WHAT?

I hate to write a bad review for an indie game shop, especially one that produced the brilliant Machinarium.  I also know I'm going against a tide of positive reviews from both users and pro reviewers I respect greatly.  Apparently, I have no heart or soul.

But seriously...what the hell?  This is not a game.  It's a trippy surreal click through random psychodelic cutscenes  with no apparent goal or purpose.  Yes, I know there is (sort of) a bad guy and a goal, but that doesn't really have much to do with any given scene.  Lots of people describe the art as "beautiful" or "charming" but it's all just minimlist soft-focus psychodelia.  Maybe if you were REALLY stoned it would be awesome, but otherwise it's just odd.

And I'm somebody who really appreciates weird and surreal indie games.

The main problems:

1) There's no emotional connection to the characters or environment, like in Machinarium.  If you CARE about what you're clicking on, games like this can be a lot of fun.  But I can't even tell WHAT I'm clicking on most of the time.  (Unless it's just another goddamn leaf or berry.)

2) It's all random "click-on-everything-and-see-what-happens".  If there's no intentionality, there's no puzzle solving, and no game.  Just a lot of clicking on random stuff to get random effects (that sometimes move the "story" forward).

So...no.  Just...no.  I loved Machinarium and I hope they make a sequel, but this game is the polar opposite, and I cannot recommend it.
