36251784.review:
This game is quite relaxing and the art is unique, interesting, and gorgeous. There is a bit of a more random element to this game compared to other point and click adventure games, but I still really enjoyed it. I liked collecting all the creature cards and looking at the art. It does not do anything, but it's an interesting and creative little feature. Be prepared to run around a lot in confusingly mapped out levels. I liked the level design because it is different, however, even with the mini map I did get lost a few times. 
I would recommend purchasing this game in a bundle or on sale since it does have a limited amount of playthrough, and is short. I finished it within six hours, but I am going to go back and get the rest of the achievements later so if you play games like me (extremely slowly) you will get your money's worth. One tip that might be obvious to other people but it took me a while to figure out is when you have an item in your inventory you can only apply it in the room it is supposed to be applied to. So, if you go to take it out of your inventory and it does not budge then you know it is not needed in that room. That feature definitely made figuring out the puzzles easier for me. 
In conclusion, if you enjoy relaxing, atmospheric, slower-paced, random, point and click adventure games I would highly recommend. If you are the kind of player that wants to play a game that is fast-paced this is not the game for you.

36227086.review: If you want a short description of the game play in "Botanicula," it's "random" and "arbitrary."  From that, you can probably guess that I'm not recommending the game.  Yes, as others have said, the visuals and sound are wonderful.  But, the game play is just silly.  In general, it consists of randomly clicking (or possibly dragging -- it's not obvious) on things on each screen a random number of times until a random and arbitrary thing results.  Randomly, you might have to repeat the above an arbitrary number of times until some other arbitrary things happen.  Also, be warned that you cannot go back to previous levels of the game without restarting.  So, if you manage to miss something optional (i.e., for an Achievement), happen to have everything necessary to finish the level, and click on the thing that finishes the level, you're SOL.  Using a walk-through, I managed to drag my way through level 4 of the game's 6 levels.  Looking at what was in level 5, I threw up my hands in disgust and quit (and I'm a completionist).  If you're one of the people who like other Amanita Design games, you'll probably love this one.  But, for the rest of us, just no.  Not Recommended.

36208435.review: A cute point-and-click puzzle game about a group of plant-like friends on a quest to save their home from an invasion of parasitic creatures. Progressing through the game usually relies on the characters finding certain items, which you collect by solving small situational puzzles like picking the right character to solve a problem, beating an NPC at a minigame, or manipulating the environment in some fashion. The biggest challenge in these usually comes from which mechanic to rely on (i.e. clicking on an item vs. clicking [i]near[/i] it vs. click-and-drag), but that doesn’t detract too much from the game. Part of this may stem from the absence of dialogue and text, but I think it was the right stylistic choice to add to the game’s charm. The world, art style, and tone all play off one another well, making it fun just to take your time and click around each screen to see what you might unearth. Recommended for fans of puzzle games and anyone who wants a game that encourages them to slow down and give their mind a light challenge.

36144109.review:
[h1]Genre:[/h1]
Point & Click Indie Puzzler.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
+ You have a party of 5 strange creatures to guide through an even stranger - yet intriguing world, by point & click puzzles that are original, with stunningly beautiful artwork and charm!  Save their world from the evil Botan-vampire (Botanicula) sucking the life-force from life in order to grow its own kind.
+ Beautiful, quirky and strangely attractive music soundtrack & sound effects.
+ Characters and atmosphere have charm.
+ Each party member has it's own puzzle solving ability.
+ A streak of humor runs through the gameplay from start to finish.
+ Built-in save feature.
+ No perma-death, no lives.
+ Basic tutorial, keeping things intriguing that encourages experimentation.
+ No keyboard needed, only mouse.
+ Play-time to completion is about 2 hours, a indie point & click puzzler fits that perfect time amount that your brain would want.
+ Memorable game for the rest of your life.
+ Playtime a solid 3 hours. 

[h1]Difficulty:[/h1] 
+ Delightful game and that perfect amount of challenge from start to finish.
+ Puzzles are new, fresh, stylistic, easy-to-comfortable challenge, rewarding.
+ Not for the hardcore puzzle gamer, but they'll still want to do a play-through as the game is worth the exp.

[h1]Replayablity:[/h1]
+ 2/5 Rarely
- Once completed, you feel rewarded & content. One of those games that you'll want to play again in a few years to relive the exp.

[h1]Graphics & Artwork:[/h1]
+ High quality indie digital artwork for its 2011 time that will always hold up due to its originality & strangeness.
+ Has a art & bizarre feel to it like the fabulous 1973 animated science fiction film 'Fantastic Planet', but made more towards the innocence of the inner-child.
+ Every section of the game has an original setting and creatures to keep you feeling refreshed & entertained. 

[h1]Overall Rating:[/h1]
⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5 Stars) Great Game!!
+ Game is a digital piece of art and a indie masterpiece.
+ Worth $3-$5, and is contently on 75% off sale throughout the year.
+ Leaves you wanting more from the developer!
+ Must-have game for your library!

-------

For additional game reviews please visit: http://steamcommunity.com/id/LordOfDarkFlame/recommended/

35520939.review:
This game is very odd. But it is very beautiful. Exquisitely beautiful.

The puzzles themselves are pretty basic click-and-point types. Sometimes it's unclear what you're meant to be doing or where you're meant to go, but honestly, that doesn't matter overly. You will get there eventually.

It's the stuff that happens in-between that's the real journey. 

The game brings quirkiness and thoughtfulness in an unconventional way. You'll be desperately clicking around the screen hoping for something to help you move along, and next thing you know, there's a bunch of lil scribbly doods singing the most beautiful melody you've ever heard. Bizarre, but so beautiful.

The music in this game really is the standout for me. It's atmospheric, it's invigorating and it takes your breath away sometimes. You end up just sitting wherever you are for a bit and listening cause it's super nice. Even if you're stuck for an hour and a half on something, it's completely tolerable. Please play with the sound on. I promise you, it's a beautiful experience.

Botanicula has a good deal of replayability, as there's a lot of cool little achievements you can get. It'd be fun to like spend a day or so 100%ing this, as all achievements only require some particular clicking.

Overall, this game is one of those games that everyone needs to try when they feel like disappearing irl for a few hours and leaving an everyday mindset. It'll make you think, but it'll also make you smile, cause it's just one of those beautiful little indie gems that you come across once in a while (rhyming unintentional - but unapologetic).

Definitely Recommend (Y)

34130872.review:
I don't have much to say about this gem.

[b]What the game does right.[/b]

It's brimming with charm and personality. Every odd character and strange creature you encounter feels weird and unique. The soundtrack is brilliant, and the voice acting, if you can call it that, is spot-on. The bizarre, almost psychedelic feel of Amanita Design's games is to be found in spades within this title. It may, perhaps somewhat ironically, be one of their spaciest titles yet. 

[b]What the game does wrong.[/b]

Hardly anything. There are a few [i]very[/i] obscure puzzles to be found, and some seem to have entirely random solutions. On a few rare occassions, you might get stuck on something long enough for it to get a bit tedious. 

[b]Conclusion.[/b]

Playing through Botanicula is, in my opinion, a great way to spend an afternoon off. If you just want to kick back and spend a few hours falling in love with a strange and bizarre little world, then this game definitely delivers. I don't know that any game in recent times has made me stop and think; "What on earth?" quite as much as this one has.

Most importantly, it made me happy.

34071670.review:
I don't want to end up not mentioning Botanicula's art style and music. I found both of these to be excellent; the music above all else. It's not something I would normally sit and listen to, but it's the perfect soundtrack for this game. I love the music and how it's used here.

I played through the first four levels out of the game's entire six-level length, and while I could have played another hour or two and finished, I was not feeling any desire to keep going. The story is that you're trying to save a seed from some shadowy monsters that are pursuing you and sucking the life out of the tree and its inhabitants. The tree is big, compared to your characters, at least, who are a team of things like nuts and a mushroom, etc., who each occasionally use a unique talent to enable progress. Getting to the bottom of the tree to plant a seed seems to be the end goal, and honestly the plot doesn't seem like it's supposed to be the driving force here.

The gameplay mostly involves finding things on the screen to click and occasionally wiggle or pull the mouse around to obtain one of numerous objects you need to continue. I'm no stranger to point-and-click games. The Space Quest and Kings Quest series were some of my favorite games as a kid. However, though there are a few little changes in environment, one of the biggest problems with Botanicula is that all the environments feel at least a bit similar. In most adventure games, the environments tend to be widely varied, and I find it helps keep a game from getting boring. Many games benefit from this.

On the topic of the objects you have to obtain to progress, though...it's generally duplicate copies of the same item for an area. For instance, to complete level one, you need to find several bug-wing thingies. Then to beat level two, you need to find five keys. To beat level three, you need to find three missing children. Then to beat level four, you need to find [i]fourteen[/i] birds in a village on the tree consisting of a dozen or more little similar buildings. This became taxingly repetitious to me, and the puzzles became more and more obscure, with the 12+ buildings making it difficult to figure out if I was done or not with any given home.

I eventually had to resort to a walkthrough and found several solutions which I am certain I never would have figured out on my own, because I believed I was done in those particular buildings, having already obtained birds or seemingly having already completed everything in the buildings that there was to partake in. Navigating the walkthrough was even hell, thanks to how many of these buildings there were to check out. When an adventure game taking a long time to solve part of it while using a walkthrough, there's an issue.

When I saw/read that level 5 was labyrinthine, I called it quits. While the music and visuals are a treat, it's not enough of a treat for me to justify playing through more of this game. The 2 hours I played felt like 5 or more, which is not good. =/

Botanicula is a very entertaining short click and point game filled with tons of charm. This game kept a smile on my face throughout playing it, even getting a chuckle out of me at some points. The story is wordless and simple. That is appropriate, since a complex story would take away from the charm of the world. The sound effects given to each character combined with fun animation gives the creatures of Bontanicula their own voices and tiny story to tell. The creatures are fun to discover and click on, which the game encourages with a card collecting achievment system. As the game went on, I started to care less about the achievements and more about what cute animation would pop up when I clicked a leaf. 

The puzzles are all based on these magical creatures, appropriatly starting simpler in the beginning and gradually progressing into more difficult tasks. With the fantastical nature of the game, some of the solutions are not always obvious, and took some clicking around the screen to figure out. I had to pull out a walkthrough during one point of the game, but that was after attempting the task multiple times. With a little thinking and lots of clicking, I was able to solve the rest of the puzzles. 

If anyone is looking for a short puzzle game full of charming characters and creatures then Botanicula is a must have. While it's about a 3-4 hour play time, the $10 price tag is deserving due to the obvious time spent fleshing out the world and the creatures. There is a great ammount of polish and love put into this game. Please give it a shot!

32595282.review:
Amanita Design is one of those developers that I love to death, and in their case it's because all of their games are so unrelentingly joyful. From Samorost's kooky cosmic critters to the pleasant rustbuckets of Machinarium, their games exude pure happiness in the form of upbeat gibberish, uncomplicated puzzles, and positive themes no matter how dark individual moments may get. Botanicula is another notch in this merry belt, one that has no trouble juggling goofy vignettes with existential threats.

Once upon a time there was a very nice tree, full of little bugs and sprouts and assorted critters. Some spidery thing showed up and started devouring it all with a sort of creeping darkness, and a small band of the aforementioned critters escape with the tree's last seed. Struggling to stay one step ahead of their monstrous adversary, the critters journey through a colorful arboreal world in search of a new home and a fresh start.

What this actually means is you have five little dudes who roam around as a unit, following your clicks from screen to screen and interacting with the many living things of Botanicula's world. As an adventure game there's very little player input, relatively speaking. There's only left click (and on occasion mouse proximity has an effect) and only on specific points of interest like critters and items. You don't move your team directly, but rather click on arrows pointing to different areas.

These limitations actually serve to benefit the game, especially as the scope of the gameplay expands. Botanicula's world is strange and alien, and most of the puzzles wouldn't work at all if they required more exact input. Instead, you can just click on little creatures to make them fly or yell or burp, and as long as you do it at the right time or in the right order or at all, you can make progress. The scenes your clicks produce are so funny and heartwarming I doubt anyone will have a problem with relinquishing control for them. And then later in the game you'll get to pick specific critters on your team to do things, collect items to use in puzzles, and work through a few more nifty gimmicks.

The story is another strong point building on these basic mechanics, a remarkable feat given that it is told entirely without dialogue. The folks at Amanita have mastered the art of storytelling through action and expression and it does tremendous work here. All of the adorable denizens you meet speak in mumbly Sims-like chatter but get their points across through wild gesticulation and the occasional visual aid. This hands-off approach both heightens the impact of events (good and bad) when they occur, and also keeps the game feeling lighthearted and silly the rest of the time. You're also encouraged to experiment with everything you meet, because interacting with new critters earns you collectible cards that can score you extra scenes at the end of the game.

You'll experience the world of Botanicula through a mix of vector art and photoshopped works, a finely-blended style that gives everything just enough weight to seem real, without losing its fanciful, dreamlike energy. The peppy soundtrack follows suit with all sorts of cutely and folksy tunes to keep you engaged. The artistry on display here is rare and unique, and makes the game feel like a real treasure from its simple beginning to its unexpectedly epic conclusion. Botanicula makes another excellent entry in Amanita Design's lineup, and an unforgettable title for any fan of point-and-click adventures.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

Certainly I am not surprised by the glowing reviews for this game on the whole. You can tell a lot of love went into this game. One of the positives people put for this game is that the puzzles are challenging. This is true, and it can be a perk, but it is also where the game struggles the most. Some of the puzzles are mouse-only and require actually doing stuff, which seems both highly at odds with the 'take-your-time' puzzle style of the rest of the game and... not very good. To me this is a very strong game, but ultimately all it takes is one 'bad' puzzle to totally halt progression. And the thing is, any given level can be your 'bad' puzzle, and even if they're not brick walls, the sound effects are so in-your-face that even a temporary slow-down can be very off-putting and jarring.
 
Ultimately I REALLY want to like this game and recommend it, but a few bad puzzles make me unable to do so.

[b]What you don't do[/b]
You don't have mechanical control.  Exploring simply means clicking the button for the next screen.  Although there are puzzles, they only require observation and recognition of icons - not logical deduction to an extent that you would stop to think about.

[b]My reaction[/b]
My general feeling is that I don't have the patience for these kinds of games.  But Botanicula stands out because of its inspiring art, which conveys a kind of childish delight through many thousands of inventive and unexpected details. If you don't really play point and click games and want to try a couple, have this one at the top of the list.

Although it's short, it has a ridiculous amount of style. Imaginative critters that are crosses between insects and plants essentially, but they're really hard to describe other than that, you just have to see them in action. You go through the game interacting with these critters, you play as a small team of 5 critters trying to save the "critter tree" from being drained of all life by black "Zlo" critters. Interacting with the area will introduce you to new critters who will help you progress. It's fun to see how creative the game designers got with the critters, all having their own signature sound effects that are sometimes quite humorous. The sound design is great in this respect, having hundreds of sounds between critters and many tunes that sound like the critters singing a ditty as a group. The area design is also quite varied, going from the canopy of the critter tree to a critter village to a branching cave of more gangled critters.

The game is short, but enjoyable all the way through. Puzzles aren't too obscure or confusing, it doesn't really have a hint system but it isn't too hard to figure out what to do. Very satisfying. This game has become one of my favorite point-and-click games, due to its style, music, and sound effects.

The game runs at sub 1080p resolution. I think the max width is 1440px, the rest will have a black background. This doesn't affect things too much, but thought I should point it out. It also does not have steam UI integration, so you have to take screenshots manually, for example.

31114063.review:
[b][i]"MADE IN CZECH REPUBLIC"[/i][/b]

I can't really help myself, but when there's game that coming from Czech or Slovak Republic, I just want to get them 10/10 and 10/10 only. Nope, I'm certainly not patriot, but goddamn we can make some great games. Especially indie ones. Yes, Arma and Mafia is one thing, but Botanicula oh lord. 

Another great example of game that is indie and truly is indie. I guess you know what indie game is suppose to mean and also you know that some games are "indies" just to cover the lack of quality.

Anyway, Botanicula is truly beautiful. Basically it's for everybody but also not for everybody. When you check the images, you might say that you'd sit your child in front of that and that's game for children but it's only beacause of visuals, that might give you cartoon atmosphere, or something you've watched when you was 4 years old. But guess what, that's indie genre dudes.

You want to know how awesome Botanicula really is? Imagine some interactive picture of let's say forest. You can move your cursor whereever you want, and every object that you can see will act like that cursor is there and behave like it's there. So the leaves will move in the direction cursor went, small twigs too, nuts, chestnuts or other forest fruit. Simply said, like you was there.

Audio is on whole another level. It was done just by two guys that goes by name DVA (Bara Kratochvil & Jan Kratochvil) and they just done their work perfectly. Amanita Designs, small czech independent studio lead by Jakub Dvorsky didn't just made Botanicula, they made their impact with Machinarium and Samorost series. With their skills, DVA duo and highly highly highly interactive enviroment they have created truly great indie gem.
(Demo available - another bonus point)

[b]Bonus Point: Czech Feeling[/b]
[h1]Rating: 9/10[/h1]

[h1]I realize I'm in the vast minority, but this game just doesn't fit me.[/h1]

I can recognize that this game is very pretty, well animated, and has a charming "cute factor" going for it, but I just can't get past the nonsensical seemingly "random" events in the game.  You do things and click on things, not so much out of logic or purpose or because you know what's going to happen, but out of [i]"you just need to click on everything to see what it does"[/i] -- and some comical, weird, random things happen.  Then using a little logic you learn to click on things in the correct order and progress the story along.

I wish I liked this.  But I couldn't get past all the [i]"wait, what just happened?  Ok, that just doesn't make sense"[/i].  Which make me think of this game more as "a doodle" as opposed to "art".  It has no point.  No aim or over-arching design, message, or meaning.  Just very random and disconnected.  Yet, is well drawn and colorful and passes the time.  It's not 'art'.  It's a doodle.

Given the ratings...I'm sure it's just me.

[h1]If you like Machinarium, you'll like this.  It has the same feeling.[/h1]

30346731.review:
How do I even begin to describe this game…?

Botanicula’s visuals are soft and dreamy and really beautiful, and unlike anything I’ve seen before, surreal even! The many strange sounds all around you pull you right into this enchanted little world, and the wonderfully ambient music follows the mood of wherever you are, from sad to scary and all the way through to elatedly happy!  (“Yoohoo!” as the five little friends would shout Ü)
 
I must admit, I was slightly sceptical as to how much fun a point and click game could possibly be, but shame on me…  It brought me straight back to that childlike wonder you have when you come across something never discovered before; thinking hmmm, what might happen if I just…?

It is a think-outside-the-box puzzle game, where you have to trust your intuition and just try… anything goes, whether it’s in a little mini-game or a mini-quest, or one of the many, many puzzles; from the playfully simple ones, to the downright trying ones and finally the ones that are just extremely frustrating (yeah, talking about you caterpillar…)!

There is no tutorial, no instructions… you’re simply thrown in the deep end; so go explore, experiment and figure it out yourself… oh, and have tons of fun while you’re at it Ü!!!

Botanicula is imaginative and intuitive and to me it has been an absolutely delightful adventure! My only regret is that the journey through this magical world is way too short (the reason that I used such a long time is that I got completely, utterly, totally lost on several occasions throughout the game in the more maze-like levels; turns out I have no sense of direction in games either…) and also I suspect that much of its charm would be lost in a replay… 

It may not be for everyone, but I loved every bit of it!

Ü

First 15 min impressions:Botanicula
Verdict: Buy for <= $2.50

This is a point and click adventure game with whimsical art. You play a group of friends as they try to shelter a seed from a big evil spider that is sucking the life force out of everything it touches. There's no text, no speaking parts, and the story is entirely told via pictures and iconography.

The game reminds me of Samorost. The puzzles are simple, and there doesn't seem to be any sort of inventory. I imagine the game will be short, perhaps an hour or so.

I wouldn't spend a lot of money for this game, but it kills a little bit of time.

29905960.review:
When the stars fell from the sky they ran into the moon and fell into the earth like seeds. From those seeds sprang beautiful trees with many creatures that lived inside. But one day strange, dark parasites began consuming the life from the trees without giving anything back. There's nothing really to be done but plant a new tree so life can begin anew!

The best I can describe this is a exploration, point and click. It's beautifully drawn, with strange and lively music. The sound effects from the things you click become part of the background music. There's no dialogue, and any directions are communicated through pictures or arrows, including the plot.

This is a game where you click around to figure out the next step, moving along through trial and error. The puzzles are generous, giving you infinite lives if you mess up. Not all the puzzles reset but most of them don't need to.

My biggest complaint is that the difficulty ascension is a little awkward, going from easy, easy, much harder, ahh, WHOA, and easy-ish again. Levels four and five are the hardest and longest by far, and I had to look at guide to figure out a lot of the smaller details.

Basically it went from having one step to take to get an item, to having a more Zelda-like approach with three or four steps. There wasn't much warning that this was going to happen.

I'm not sure it's a "humourous" game but it made me smile in many places. This is a delightful point and click to explore, with well designed puzzles. Absolutely add it to your library!

29770390.review:
This game is a hell of a lot of fun. There were times I burst out laughing and other times I thought I must have taken drugs with my last cup of tea due to the wild and strange things happening in-game. At other times I just sat and enjoyed the beautiful relaxing ambience this game provides.  It is truly a game for everyone. There are puzzles in the game but they are not the focus. The point isn’t to boggle the player’s mind but to guide them to thoroughly explore this unique world while completing a number of small challenges and fetch quests along the way. If you are a completionist (like I am!) then there are over 100 creature cards to collect, which you do by completing some form of interaction with all the creatures you meet, be that helping them, scaring them away or simply clicking on every single one you can see (and some of the cards are really cute!).

Overall: 9.5

Botanicula is a really fun game with a fantastic aesthetic, brilliant creatures, beautiful music and tonnes of stunning places to explore. It’s also a pretty short game so it doesn’t  overstay its welcome and even really busy people can finish it.  With a wonderful surprise at every turn I couldn’t recommend this game more!

Breakdown

Aesthetic: 10/10

Do I really need to say anything given the screenshots above? Amanita Design is also the developer of Machinarium and Samorost 3, and all their games come with the same unique, gorgeous and charming aesthetic. The way they animate all the little creatures is amazing and every screen brings you more and more beautiful designs.

Music & Sound: 10/10 

I would buy Botanicula just for the soundtrack. The music is beautiful and relaxing, and suits the ambience of the game perfectly. There are a range of moods, from dramatic to soothing to upbeat and lively and no matter what is happening on-screen the accompanying music serves to increase the atmosphere and immersion. There are also hundreds of unique sound effects associated with the different creatures in this game that serve to highlight the different personalities of each despite the fact they never actually talk (see my characters section for more). This clever use of sound effects draws you in and makes the game even better.

Game Play: 8/10

Overall the game mechanics are very simple and there is little that could go wrong other than the usual annoyance that comes with all point & click games. When you have clicked everything on the screen and nothing at all happens you have to vent your frustration by finding the nearest guide, at which point you face-palm at how “obvious” the solution is. But that didn’t happen that often in Botanicula so the pain was kept to a minimum.

The only other minor complaint I have is that I spent quite a lot of time getting lost despite the helpful little map leaf in the corner, although that might be due to my own incompetence more than anything else.

Characters: 10/10

Another characteristic of Amanita Design games is that their characters have a tendency not to speak, instead communicating via a series of incoherent sounds. This gets no complaints from me given most voice acting is horrendous and only decreases the player’s immersion. The burbling noises made by all the creatures in Botanicula suit the game perfectly and make them all so lovable! It really is incredible how quickly you grow attached to all the various nuts, mushrooms and tiny creatures you encounter and they all have so much character. And anyway, as a biologist I feel I should point out that these little guys don’t speak human language anyway and the idea of a grub with an American accent is just silly.

Bad points?

The game could do with more settings as the options menu is barely present, but apparently the game runs on almost anything so I guess it doesn’t really need a lot of options. Other than that I really can’t think of anything bad to say!

This game is fairly pretty and cute. It has it's own unique artstyle and it shows the game the simplisity of everything. It's easy to play, fun, interesting, problem solving (not hard) which makes it relaxing and enjoyable.

This game has only music (bgm) and interactive sounds but no chatter voice. They all sound muffed while talking to one another which so make you have to focus the thought bubble to understand what they say. It is fairly easy so no hard thinking required.

The five main characters are all unique with different abilities which you would need to think slightly which one would be the one to get the key items. Their characteristics are very fun to look at as it tells what the character likes and wishes.

The music is great and the story told is clear. Like most of the game, you will understand more about the background story through the game. The black laid back tall mushroom tells you the legend so you know what is going on and by talking to all three, you know how the story might end up. Well, not exactly but an idea more or less.

The achievements in this game (just in case anyone is wondering) is fairly simple. You just have to interact with all the characters (not the main ones) to unlock their cards. I played this game for the first time and I have collected all but three without guide (except once about the duck in the oven to progress).

Overall, I highly recomment you to play this game if what you seek is leisure and enjoyment.
I am giving this game a 9 out of 10. I feel this game could slightly be better to be more enjoyable but regardless, it is a great game.

This game is very simple. Its only involves clicking the right places, or tugging.
This game is insanely hard, even unfair towards the end. Clicks are necessary at the right time in the right window at the right place. There is no help. There is no dialogue, except for some noises and more or less hidden signs. You didn't get them? Too bad, your fault. In later chapters, there is a multitude of screens, sometimes a maze, that you have to go through in the right order - with puzzles that sometimes are less than counterintuitive.
Graphics, or should I say "audiovisual presentations" are not to everyone's taste. It's clearly "art". Deal with that.

If you want to immerse in this story, go ahead. It's fun. I, for my part, followed the walkthrough and enjoyed a visual novel - without the fuss and the frustration of going through dozens of screens checking if I'd overlooked something. Like that, I actually enjoyed playing it - but you shouldn't expect more than 2-3 hours, anyway.

Oh, and I forgot to mention: There is a "Full Screen" Option to play this game. Which means that there is a large black screen with the game running in its native resolution in the middle. Which was kind of... influencing the whole experience in a negative way, because I was playing in 3440x1440. Which meant LOTS of black space. Talk about using the mouse pointer in an exact way...

29134483.review:
Botanicula is the game that converted me to the point-and-click genre, and it's all thanks to Amanita's magic touch for crafting unique adventure games.

You guide a quirky ensemble of plant-like creatures on a quest to save their home, and even though the storytelling is subtle, it's incredibly impactful. I've played through multiple times, each session making me more enamoured with the details—especially the soundtrack.

This game is a labor of love from the devs and serves as a gateway to Amanita's other gems like Samorost and Machinarium. If you're hesitant, wait for a sale, but trust me—it's a must-play for fans of story-driven solo gaming.

29098375.review:
Botanicula is an average point and click game that just barely makes up for it in a cute world of plants and creatures.

Pros:
- The game takes place in a lovely environment full of plants and life. The colors are nice too.
- You control a group of people? Objects? I don't know have to describe them. You control a group of nature heroes, and its funny to see them react to the environment. 
- I don't normally like when games have no spoken words, but in this case I think it worked. Nothing in this game talks, and its charming.
- I enjoyed the music. There is just one part in the game where you control the instruments being played by two creatures, and its entertaining to hear the music develop.

Cons:
- The controls (can I even call them controls, all you do is click on things) were very unclear. It was at times difficult to figure out how and when to click on something, even when I knew exactly what to do in that situation. That was annoying especially toward the end. There is a section where you have to get a light orb from a pod, and you have to click on the white arrows in a VERY specific way to get the orb. I knew exactly what I had to do, but I had to resort to a youtube video to figure out how to pass this part.
- There is no way I found to make the game full screen, so I was playing with a black frame around the game. It was distracting.
- Steam overlay wouldn't work while I played, so I was unable to see achievements when they popped up. I also had to alt tab to get to a browser.
- When I completed the game, the main menu only gave me an option to play a new game, so I guess there is no way to go to specific chapters in the game. I hate when games do this.

Botanicula is very bizarre and trippy which was nice to see. The story was very basic and was satisfying in the end. I can't say I'd recommend this game at regular price. Definitely pick this one up on a sale. 

There are no jump scares, but there are dark sections toward the end with cartoony-creepy creatures. I wouldn't describe it as scary either.

29087931.review:
I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a litlle bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total dissapointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!

The review will be constructed into 5 parts:
1. Game description (from what i've seen in the time i've played).
2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.
3. Pros/Cons.
4. Final thoughts.
5. Rating

So let's beggin...

1. Game description:

Point and click adventure at it’s finest. The team behind Machinarium did not disappoint. I don’t want to spoil anything, let’s just say that without saying a word this game tells a better story than a lot of other games. 
The atmosphere is brilliant. The sound and music mixes with the actions you take and on every screen there is something that you can do, even if it is not quest related. 

2. Did i finish the game? YES

The game is fairly short if you know what you are doing, however if you take your time to explore the environment and find all the hidden stuff it will take you a while. 
I will come back to this game one day to find the last hidden creature.


3. Pros/Cons.

PROS:
- Beutiful visuals
- Superb sound and music
- Interesting story
- Tons of hidden stuff to find and explore

CONS:
- None

4. Final thoughts:

Just get it! You won’t be disappointed. Again HB manages to throw in a game that blows me away. This is one of those games you come home to after a hard day at work. Just sit down relax and get absorbed in the story and atmosphere. 

5. Rating

10/10

Botanicula is a point-and-click adventure but also a game of exploration. It doesn't take you by the hand, you have to experiment to find out what you are supposed to be doing. Everything moves, makes sounds, reacts in some way and you have to find the pattern that makes it all come together. Almost every location has it's own puzzle, 123 in total (you get in-game cards for completing them). It is a difficult game, sometimes a silly game, always an immensly satisfying game. The music and sound as well as the art style is simply amazing. 

My only criticism is that I needed only 4 hours to complete it. I wanted more! 

I recommend this game for everyone who loves point-and-click adventures and wants to experience a somewhat different take on the genre. And for everyone who loved this game I strongly recommend the other adventures from Amanita Design: Machinarium and Samorost 1-3. They are all fantastic.

28694346.review:
At first when I purchased Botanicula, I wasn't too sure I would like it. Truth be told, I only bought it because the characters and art style looked super cute. I never really had any experience with point-and-click games - at least not in a long while - so this purchase was something of a risk for me. But, every risk has the possibility of becoming a sweetass reward, and, now that I've beaten the game, I can definitely consider my purchase of Botanicula to be just that. 

As I've mentioned, the characters and art style are super cute, and they surely have enough charm to match its cuteness. I couldn't stop smiling and giggling throughout my 6 hour playthrough due to the oodles and oodles of OMGEVERYTHINGISSOCUTENESS. Like, if you wanna see what I'm talking about, watch this 27 second YouTube video I made of some singing frogs from the game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jLo49T7z-Jw

So, yeah: The game's as cute as a bug, and considering I have, like, 87 mental disorders involving the symptom depression, that's pretty important to me. But, what's also important to me is for there to be some sort of meaning to the game. Like, why are these bugs just going around talking to singing frogs and solving puzzles (more on the puzzles in a moment)? Well, the game does a really good job of explaining its story in a way that provides empathy for the characters' plight without using words to do so. Like, the game doesn't use any words at all. Everything is expressed using imagery and emotional gibberish; it's adorable and heart-touching at the same time. By the end of the game, I was so determined to help the buggos, that I didn't mind failing at puzzles again and again and again - so long as I knew that eventually I'd perservere, and Mr. Twig and his buddies would eventually be happy again!

The puzzles themselves are, well, they're certainly satisfying to solve! Just about every time you solve a puzzle, the characters go all "YooHoo!" and it's THE CUTEST THING EVER OMG! I'm normally pretty terrible at puzzles (I blame those aforementioned mental disorders), so I eventually needed a guide to help me through the game. However, one thing I did notice was that it was also pretty difficult to identify where exactly puzzles were supposed to be. Like, not just what you were supposed to do in a puzzle, but what exactly was a puzzle? Where to start a puzzle? Sometimes it was tough to just get started, and I feel like this might be a problem for more people than just myself, especially near the end of the game. There's this awfully mazy-like area, and it practically forces you to use a guide for at least some of it. For me this wasn't a really big deal, since I didn't really buy this game for its puzzles anyway, but I could definitely see some people becoming upset by this. 

So, there ya have it: my feelings about this game. I'm sure you're all very scared now by all of this, but you shouldn't be scared of purchasing this game, at least not if you like cute things and puzzles. Very, very, very nice game, and I'm looking forward to playing the other games done by Amanita Design.

<3

Pros:
- Incredibly charming in every aspect possible
- Clever storytelling that doesn't rely on words 
- Atmospheric soundtrack and sound effects
- Interactive environment
- Puzzles are generally satisfying to solve

Cons:
- Easy to get lost
- Puzzles are a little too difficult to identify sometimes

28665064.review:
I am a bit back and forth on this one. On one hand the style, animation, sounds and overall design is really cute and sucks you in the game. On the other hand, there are a few puzzles where there is too much trial and error going on, where you just click things and hope it works. And even some spots where you have to click on the same spot multiple times to get the answer. I think this should never be in a point and click, even if I'm rewarded in between clicks with different animations. 

Still, I really like the overall feel, and think that in a sale it's worth the price. Most solutions are genuinely cute and give you a nice animation of the resolve. It's a bit on the short side, but that's actually just how I like my games. 

Overall a yes, even if some parts drag on and put you out of the game.

25513674.review:
Delightful, clever game; this is one I recommend to all my friends who are looking for point-and-click puzzle games. You play as a team of five seed-ish characters traveling around a tree threatened by fuzzy-spider creatures, and have to solve puzzles to reach some regions or get some resources. The map unlocks after you've done a few of the initial puzzles.


The graphics are wonderful; audio is excellent at giving a sense of mood and direction without words; puzzles are varied enough to be challenging. There's likely to be at least a few that are frustrating because of that - there's something for everyone's preferred style, which means there's also something that's outside of everyone's comfort zone. (For me, it was the ant maze.) One section has a couple-dozen separate rooms, each with a puzzle-bit to complete, and it can be hard to keep track of which ones you've completed; making notes on paper may help. 

Click on everything - most of the achievements are side-events rather than part of the main puzzle track. Fortunately, "everything" is mostly charming extras, with cute creatures bouncing around and plants unfurling and making charming noises.

Highly recommended, like everything from Amanita Design.

24411959.review:
Probably, Botanicula - one of the cutest games that I had seen. This is one of those games whose charm lies in its simplicity and even a certain naivety, combined with excellent art-style.

Storyline is fully revealed in the first minute of the game. Our brave heroes must save last tree seed from voracious spider-like parasites and... that is it. Well, on the way from the top of tree to its roots, heroes will visit quite strange, unexpected and unpredictable places. Here I must say that sometimes Botanicula seemed for me, well... too eclectic. The first part of the game has a beautiful and clearly defined style, but in the middle of the game appeared... inappropriate elements; for my taste, they just do not fit in original style.

Last part of the game is excellent, it offers an impressive contrast with the beginning. Live intertwining branches, filled with sunlight and scurrying creatures, are replaced by dark and eerie domain of parasites. The tree is dying. I was deeply impressed by last scene... and inspired by hope. The idea is simple and clear: despite everything, do not despair.

As for the gameplay. It is very simple, puzzles are not difficult but well designed and interesting enough. There is almost no inventory management and, in my opinion, it is good, because I do not think that collecting weird stuff and guessing how all this junk should be used, is a necessary element of good game. There are some arcade mini-games, they are well designed and fits perfectly in the mood of the game.

World of Botanicula is inhabited by a variety of strange creatures and I humbly advise you to not hurry. Explore the game, click everywhere and see what happens then. In many cases, your curiosity will be rewarded with short funny scene. Botanicula is filled with humor, this game is truly created with love.

I really liked the soundtrack, this strange and charming melodies, filled with buzzing and other strange sounds, it creates a very special atmosphere. Great job!

Well. I sincerely recommend Botanicula. Odd, touching, optimistic... that is it. Not a masterpiece, maybe, but close enough.

23565205.review:
[i]Botanicula[/i] is the second full-length game from Amanita Design, and it's absolutely amazing. Compared with [i]Machinarium[/i], their first full-length (and also amazing) game, [i]Botanicula[/i] is a much more colourful approach, to both visuals and level design. In each level, there are obvious objectives you work towards to go onto the next section, however it's extremely rewarding and fun to just interact with the environment. There are so many uniquely designed creatures and beautifully drawn scenes, I can't imagine anyone wanting to rush through this game. 

The sound design is also fantastic. All the sound effects for movement, creatures and various objects in the world make the game wonderful to play through. Every time I've played through this game, I have a huge smile on my face. DVA's soundtrack is also very well done; I even bought it on vinyl!

I would give this a final score of 9.6/10. My only complaint is that there's a lot to keep track of during the fifth level, which can make it drag on and feel a little tedious. And occasionally, there are moments where I felt like I was just clicking for a solution; something that is too common in point-and-click games! As well, it would have been awesome to play this in higher resolution on my MacBook Pro w/ Retina display, however there does not appear to be an option. The game would look incredibly beautiful at a 2560x1600 resolution! Other then that, this is a near-flawless game. Don't get this on a sale, pay full price. I did when it launched, and Amanita is one of the few companies I would do it for again and again.

23033270.review:
[h1]Short version: 79%[/h1]
Botanicula is an excellent voiceless surrealist point ‘n’ click adventure, a great fit in the Amanita Design library. Two extremely long chapters hold back its final score though, as they just drag on for way too long.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
Before Samorost 3, Botanicula was probably the longest Amanita Design game with its 4-6 hours of play time (as opposed to the 30-120 minutes we are used from them). It is also unique in their portfolio in the sense that it has a cohesive central plot line about a group of sentient plants and their journey along the branches of a life-giving, glowing tree. Their task is no smaller than saving the last seed of their tree from an evil light-eating spider-like monster and its numerous offspring.
Still, at its core, it is a surrealist adventure, this time showcased in the many small sub-stories that form each chapter. If you are looking for all those unexplainable moments, like a random onion using a fishing rod to get a mount to ride on, you’ll find those in abundance.

While it was commendable that they tried to make a full-fledged adventure game, its size also presents a drawback. This is most notorious in the underground section, which is so full of running around that it gets actually boring. But I also could mention the city, where the usual voiceless and textless approach adds an unnecessary difficulty modifier to the often unexplained puzzles. Sometimes progress can be more of a question of luck than problem solving skills.

With all these put together, Botanicula is a strange beast, because I cannot recommend it for those who are not familiar with this studio’s games. But if you already have some experience with Amanita Design, then Botanicula may be among your favourite adventure games.

22952848.review:
I was moved to write a review for this delightful game after watching a Extra Credits video on the value of short games. I can't say I remember how long it took to complete everything in Botanicula, but every minute was worth it. Rarely have I seen a game that captured whimsy in such a poignant way. With no dialogue other than sounds and grunts, the game manages to portray a story of despair & hope, longing & belonging and wonder at the vastness of everything. 

The visuals are just sumptious. The soundtrack is perfectly suited and individualized, like a theme song for each character or unique moment. I don't think you could ask for a more compelling take on a puzzle quest type game, that never has to beat you over the head that it's a puzzle quest.

I don't think I could more highly praise the work of the designers and production team. This one is worth every moment you play the game, even if it only takes you a few hours to finish.

22712282.review:
An absolutely beautiful game!  It has distinctive animation and a clever plot all conveyed with no words and a gentle,  pleasing soundtrack which just envelopes you into the world of the game.  

The puzzles within the game are unusual and make you think outside of the box.  In fact, the whole game makes you think outside of the normal challenges you find in most adventure games. They are clever and all very "let's try this and see what happens"  (e.g. if you touch this, what happens and how will that reaction help you).  The game sparked an intuitive exploration mode in me that I didn't know I had and I enjoyed every moment of wandering in its world and not just racing through it to find an ending.  

A bonus for me is that this is not a violent game other than trying to do away with a bad spider.  This may sound like a lame plot to most hardcore game players who are used to destroying enemies, dominating warloads, and relying on magic and combat to find a just end for the hero.  It isn't.  The fact that the game can be totally interesting and thoughtful without those trappings makes the game magical. 

I hope the developers create more games like this.  Kudos!  I highly recommend the game to all ages (although the very young might want assistance every now and then but how fun would that be to actually interact with your child to solve the game).

21771024.review:
It's not often that a game can woo me with a memorable experience without ever saying a word of dialogue, but this one certainly did.

Botanicula is nature personified in all the most enthralling ways - you have this little party of seedlings of various types who explore different regions of this massive tree together, learning more not only about its inhabitants, but its history and its looming crisis as well. Everything you experience here has a charming, hand-crafted feel to it, from the characters to the backgrounds - even the soundtrack is a lovely, quirky mix of accapella in a sound reminiscent of the band Sigur Ros.

For some people, point & click gameplay may not be the most exciting, but then again, most people who will enjoy this have played a few point & click adventures, so the gameplay isn't too surprising. Aside from a  few clickable areas that seem to keep you guessing a little bit too long, It's fairly easy to navigate. If you manage to make it through the game in one playthrough, you will definitely be staring back at the screen in awe. It's no Final Fantasy VII, but the sense of accomplishment after struggle is certainly there.

If you enjoy indie games, games with a hand-made touch, or games that are great at visual storytelling, then pick this up - you'll be glad you did, like I did :)

21405999.review:
Botanicula is an aesthetic-driven game whose story is told visually through pictures and images. This is similar to Machinarium which is developed by the same team. However, the setting is completely different. You follow a team of magical insects as they try to save their tree. 

Optionally, along the way you meet a host of magical insects whose mysteries you are encouraged to unravel and are rewarded with a card for your "Bestiary" collection. The cards are secondary though and merely there to represent that you have explored all the mysteries with that particular insect, and you can move on.

The mysteries themselves are hypothesis-oriented. You attempt various different experiments on that screen until eventually, you figure out how the magical insect operates. Unlike Machinarium, Botanicula has barely any item-collection oriented puzzles (and those it has are really obvious - as in an insect asking for a specific item), so most of the puzzles can be solved on the screen you are on. This lowers the scope of brute forcing and makes the actual puzzle solving a lot more enjoyable. When you need some extra knowledge or oomph from another screen, it completely becomes obvious that you've run out of actions and there's enough to explore that you can leave and then come back later with some novel insight.

However, while I have not referenced a walkthrough once and find this game charming and satisfying, I have noticed other reviewers saying that the puzzles are frustrating and very difficult. So keep that in mind and perhaps this is one of those games that you should DEMO before committing to, to see whether it's frustrating or fun for you. 

All in all, a pleasurable and enjoyable experience from a team that I will be following in their future endeavours.

Botanicula is a beautiful, soothing children's story set in an alien world of plant and insect people. The tree of life is being invaded by leeching spider monsters and you must go on an adventure to save your friends and grow a new tree. A story told with child-like wonder through charming art, point-and-click puzzles and quirky music all without words! 

Botanicula has a folksy, weird-but-heartfelt atmosphere where you will drink psychedelic wine, listen to wordless folk tales, watch puppet shows, ride inside a yellow submarine creature's head, and find miniature ostriches to run inside wheels and power the propeller that lifts a village of nut people out of harm's way. It reminds me of playing with seed propellers, nuts and rocks as a kid and imagining tiny people. A joy to play.

20734305.review:
Botanicula is by far one of the most charming games I've ever played. Everything about it takes me back to simpler times when I was so easily entertained. If you have any appreciation for a light-hearted point-and-click adventure, then you will greatly enjoy Botanicula. 

The gameplay is entirely point-and-click. You will have to solve puzzles and complete fetch quests to progress through the story. Botanicula does a wonderful job of staying fresh through its visual and sound design--i never got tired of doing practically the same thing repeatedly. It also helps that Botanicula will probably only last you a few hours at most. It could have gotten tedious had it lasted much longer. The puzzles are never too difficult either. I had to look up solutions to a couple of parts but ended up kicking myself for not having the patience of figuring it out. The story is light, and is driven by the characters' actions. There is no dialogue whatsoever, rather any information regarding the story is told through pictures and short cutscenes. It's a cute element that suits the game.

One of Botanicula's greatest strengths is its visual design. The color palette really pops off the screen, and it adds to the effect when purposeful colorless segments come into play. The bright and joyful colors are complimented by jovial little characters that you control. Each of the characters in your group eventually play a significant role in puzzles throughout the game. While one of them is much more important than the others when it comes to the story, each character has a part to play. Besides the protagonists you control you'll come across several other botanical creatures you can interact with. Playing their little games or simply interacting with them earns you a card with said creature on it that you can collect. If you find them all you get a little bonus after the credits role! All these tiny creatures are diverse in design and range from adorable to mildly frightening. I had fun finding the rascals and discovering their quirks.  

The overall sound design goes hand in hand with the cute aesthetics. I found myself laughing out loud as I heard the silly sounds some of the creatures made. From speech to the sound of movement, everything was spot on to me. Even the darker, scary enemies were well done and felt intimidating in a game where I knew very well that I couldn't be harmed. The music isn't particularly memorable, but I never thought it was bad at any points either. I suppose it just gets the job done.

I loved Botanicula. It's fun, adorable, heartwarming and if I ever have kids someday, I would love to play this with them. This is definitely worth your time.

20722373.review:
This game is without question weird. And that’s definitely to its favor.
[i]Botanicula[/i] is a point-and-click adventure game about the faunal flora residents of a fantastical tree trying to stop a dark, arachnid-like entity from destroying everything they know. If it sounds strange already, then trust me when I say you don’t know the half of it.
To begin, gameplay is standard to the genre; as the player, your job is to explore the grand extent of the tree from the dramatically miniscule perspective of your band of five oddball characters. In your adventuring, you are provided the opportunity to interact with nearly every aspect of your environment, collecting items, receiving and completing small quests and challenges, solving puzzles, and unraveling the simple and yet still fascinating narrative before you, often making use of the individual assets of your tiny arboreal team to do so, and all without the game ever uttering more than a few words of human speech in the process.
Using that as a steppingstone, I transition into aesthetics. The artwork is absolutely beautiful, reminiscent of the animated fair of Tim Burton. Yet, even as there is a bizarre and almost twisted nature to the visuals, the presentation remains almost perpetually lighthearted (most of the time). Nearly every aspect of the tree that the small band of main characters inhabits has a life of its own and each is immensely unique from one to the next (so much so, there’s even a card-collecting mechanic within the game that showcases a solid plethora of these many faces whenever the player takes interest in looking back). Meanwhile, the main team itself is an odd collective of friends who, while not given heavy character development, are filled with heart and personality. Matching up with the strange visuals and dreamlike presentation is an almost unearthly soundtrack from Czech musical group DVA, who also aided in other aspects of the final product.
As I stated earlier, there is almost no true verbal dialogue outside of the intentionally indecipherable mumbles of its characters, and next to no text of any kind; the entirety of the story is recalled and played out on screen as if on a stage. Nevertheless, it is an engaging narrative, even as it is a simple one. In the end, the game isn’t especially lengthy, nor is it predominantly difficult (I, considering myself a less impressive gamer, was able to complete it in right around 5 hours); additionally, like most games in its subset genre, it tends to be a casual experience without an exceptional abundance of high-velocity or high-intensity moments during play. Do any of these facts diminish the value of this game? My answer is an emphatic no. When approaching almost any artistic product—be it a game, a song, a movie, or anything else—it’s important to remember that rarely, if ever, will a piece of art appeal to everyone; even the most popular or widely received products will have people who simply don’t enjoy it the way others do, and this one is certainly not exempt by any means.
[i]Botanicula[/i] is definitely a strange piece of work. It’s a wild adventure that takes place almost entirely in a tree; it’s a bizarre introduction to a lovable cast and a beautiful world; it’s a story without many words, yet it is filled with all sorts of heart and humor [i](sometimes irreverent—discerning gamers/parents, feel free to message me for more details)[/i]; it’s a relatively calm, somewhat brief, light-hearted game that had me entranced, entertained, and engaged all the way through.
To sum it up shortly: it was pretty weird, and it was pretty awesome.

20268081.review:
I just took the weekend for 2 of Amanita's games: Machinarium and Botanicula.

If you've ever played Machinarium before (and you liked it), I'm telling you now that Botanicula is just as amazing. Get it, play it, enjoy it! The graphics are lighter and more colourful in general, the puzzles are only a little less challenging (so no need for a "cheating" notebook on the upper right corner, but you still need to crack your head every once in a while), and the story is just as adorable.

If you haven't played any of this studio's games, however, allow me to summarise without spoiling you: Botanicula tells the story of a group of plant-y friends who embark on a journey to save the tree of light from darkness (embodied by spiders). Since it's a puzzle game, you need to complete several tasks to get items and continue to the next level. You will find a total of 123 creatures, each representing a creature card that will be given to you, and which you can look at by selecting the deck on the upper left corner. Take your time, though! There are plenty of Easter eggs along the way (golden cards, and also your Steam achievements) that don't all need to be found for you to go through to the end.

100% recommend if you're into logic and thinking while having fun.

I personally loved it.

i went into Botanicula not at all having played any of the other dev's games nor knowing what to expect but i was immediately pulled in. the art style is so unique (at least in my opinion) and wonderful all throughout; the gameplay is easy and i found no bugs or the like the whole time i played [though the puzzles Could occassionally get tricky]. the soundtrack to this game is, in my humble opinion, composed of entirely lovely pieces that have left me searching for tracks online. i really wish there was a way to buy it along with the game, but sadly, that option doesn't exist at the moment.

tl;dr - botanicula is a fairly short (depending on how good you are at puzzles) game that does a GREAT job in creating atmosphere with all its effects. 10/10, would purchase again. love these tree creatures.

20062205.review:
1 minute into the game: What the hell is going on?
2 hours and 40 minutes into the game: No, seriously, what the HELL is going on?

This game is, in a word, strange. But I think that's part of the charm. I originally bought this on the cheap due to its unique visuals. I knew literally nothing else about it, and it sat uninstalled in my library for a while before I decided, "Hey, why not? IS it actually any good?"

Had I known beforehand it was a point-and-click style game, I don't think I would have purchased it. When I picked it up in a Humble Bundle, I wasn't even really thinking twice about it. I'm glad I didn't, or I would have missed out on quite the unique experience. This game has quite an array of puzzles to solve, all while presenting you with beautifully simplistic sounds, visuals, and humor. I'm not sure it's something I'd find myself coming back to over and over again, but I missed quite a few cards on my first run through so it might be worth it to come back at least once to see what I missed! If you're looking for something to relax with and spend an afternoon on, this is a great game to pick up.

19832253.review:
Aventura gráfica de estética 2D donde nos sumergiremos en un fantástico universo imaginario de la mano de un variopinto grupo de pequeños seres, los cuales viajarán a través de los confines de este para encontrar la forma de combatir un extraño mal que amenaza su mundo.

Con mecánica “point and click” y sin diálogos, el título nos transporta mediante sus originales diseños y su cuidada banda sonora a una experiencia de juego diferente de la acostumbrada, donde nada se puede dar por supuesto dentro de sus magníficos y coloridos escenarios llenos de vida que, poco a poco, nos abren las puertas a un nuevo mundo plagado de peculiaridades y cosas por descubrir mientras avanzamos resolviendo retos y experimentando con el entorno y sus habitantes.

En conclusión, un interesante título muy cuidado y entretenido, dentro del buen hacer al que nos tienen acostumbrado sus desarrolladores, Amanita design, creadores de aventuras gráficas como Samorost o Machinarium. Por desgracia hay que mencionar que la duración de este es bastante escasa y, aunque no resta valor al juego, si hace discutible su precio de venta, el cual es recomendable adquirir con un buen descuento, por el resto es una propuesta estupenda que agradará a los aficionados al género. Bastante recomendable.

I loved this game. Beautiful art, relaxing game with a few challenging points--if you're more gifted with mazes/maps than I am, though, you might finish it more quickly! I finished it some time ago and am still thinking about it. I might even play it again to see if I can get 100% of the achievments.

Speaking of, the only two negative points that I found are: 

1) You have to create a save point at the end of each level if you want to go back to try to find creatures for the acheivements. I found most of them just by playing the game, but as there's no list within the game, it's hard to tell without closely scrutinizing the Steam achievements. Didn't realize that I couldn't go back to individual levels until I'd already completed a couple and moved on.

2) There are a couple of annoying sounds that repeat many, many times.

Those are pretty minor points, though, so I'd give Botanicula an overall 9/10. Would definitely recommend.

17515008.review:
Pros
*Great visual design and animation. Great music and the atmosphere and non-verbal story-telling is really cool, similar to Machinarium (same devs) as far as characters speaking through picture speech bubbles. I like the contrast of the very vibrant, colorful, livid, lively, green environment and some parts where it's dying and a part close to the end when things get a bit dark, but no very heavy.
*Would probably be great for children 
*Can run on very low-end computers

Cons
*There are only a couple things that were really puzzles. Mostly I was just clicking a bunch of stuff watching all kinds of weird (yet entertaining) things happen before it gave me whatever item I needed to proceed at the time. 
*It's very abstract (which I like) and not really as much of a little world that Machinarium was, having really randomness to the different places and organisms you meet. Which I think Machinarium is a better game overall, telling a more cohesive narrative versus this game's sort of child drawing story (that could be taken as a negative or a positive). 
*The game was really short. I have 2.7 hours on this game and that was with clicking on everything I could find, though I didn't quite 100% it but I wasn't far off. I had little to no problem with the "puzzles" so I went through it pretty fast but even someone getting stuck a lot, if that's even possible, would still beat it fairly quickly. I think $10 is a bit pricey for a game that has little replay value and is so short. 

In summary, this was an enjoyable experience especially at first glance at how wildly out there it was. It's a very sort kid's dream and occasionally nightmare with how abstract it is. But it was very short. I liked Machinarium more.

17035804.review: I cannot express in words my absolute love for this game. As other reviews have said, it's a point-and-click puzzle/adventure game where you play as a group of five little seedlings, each a perfect stereotype of the members of a typical group of friends. For example, the small chestnut-like seedling is the group leader, taking charge of situations and being the one to stand for the group as a whole, whereas the big, kind of walnut-looking one is the stereotypical goofy member of the group, the one who's there for his comic relief and his Hufflepuff heart of gold. For a game with not a single bit of English dialogue, it speaks volumes with the art style, soundtrack (which is phenomenal, by the way), and the movements and actions of each seedling. There's even a strange type of humor, unexplainable in words, that stems from the adorable personalities of the tiny creatures all throughout the game. I've played through Botanicula twice now, and I plan on playing again. The charm this title has, as well as the emotional attachment I've acquired for a handful of seeds, keeps me coming back for more, and that's perfectly fine with me.

17011157.review:
Botanicula is a perfectly thought plant universe; the story takes place essentially in the branches of a tree, and in every board we can observe the life which swarms (a bee which crosses the screen, the wind in leaves, the wildlife which loafs about on branches, etc.). In this way, the whole game is peaceful and pleasant.

The scenario is basic: malefic spiders threaten the vegetable world. Very fortunately, a group of small characters is going to oppose and make everything to save the world!

And it is this band of small characters that you are going to control: Mr. Lantern, the clumsy leader; Mr. Twig, the music lover; Mr. Poppyhead, the acrobat; Mrs Mushroom, the magician; and Mr. Feather, the aerial.

We control all the group of characters at the same time, it will be just necessary to select sometimes one character in particular to carry out an action, but that does not go farther. The objective of levels in levels is to collect objects to get back other objects, change zone or simply beat up spiders. All the actions are thus made with the mouse, both for moving and doing something in particular.

There are no dialogues. We make us the story understand with drawings or dreams

Botanicula is not a really difficult game. Riddles will put only few problems to be resolved. About 3 or 4 hours are required to finish it.

The soundtrack is very pleasant, in particular all the small sound effects which stuff every level (in particular the little "yippee" of our little heroes each time a quest is successful). Visually, it is beautiful and well thought. There is a lot of funny situations, especially because the heroes are, as all the heroes of video games, rather stupid.

Conclusion: Botanicula is a good game experience and a beautiful concept and universe.

16653419.review:
[h1]AT A GLANCE[/h1]
(Full review follows below)

[list]
[*] [b]Game Name:[/b] Botanicula
[*] [b]Original Release:[/b] 2012
[*] [b]Genre Tags:[/b] Point & Click; Adventure; Casual; Puzzle
[*] [b]My Overall Grade:[/b] A-
[*] [b]Estimated Playtime (Campaign):[/b] 4-7 hours
[*] [b]Multiplayer Aspect:[/b] None
[*] [b]Recommended To:[/b] Established fans of the genre; Novelty seekers; Casual gamers
[/list]	

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]
[b]Botanicula[/b] is an incredibly charming, short-and-sweet game which is frequently described as having a “happy” identity.  It is a point-and-click style, casual adventure game that takes you on a wondrous ride through a microcosmic fantasy world inhabited by bugs and critters.  Any fan of point-and-click, adventure-puzzle games will likely enjoy the experience. 

The best feature of this game is the overall charm inherent in its delivery.  The art style and the soundscape together create the alluring atmosphere of the game.  The simple story is told through animations and emotion-filled sounds rather than through text and dialogue.  Despite the simple storytelling mechanics, all the characters you play and those you meet are uniquely interesting and charming.

The actual gameplay requires you to progress the story by solving puzzles via interaction with the world around you.  It will be mostly trial and error; but nothing is too daunting.  I felt the puzzles were a good balance of tricky and sensible; but they are not all necessarily logical.  You will have to think about the puzzles in terms of the wacky game-world dynamics. 

The game is rather short, even shorter if you rush through the main objectives.  It is more enjoyable (and still somewhat short) if you take the time to interact with everything and see what you can discover.  There are plenty of hidden “Easter eggs” and collectibles scattered throughout the game to cater to those who enjoy treasure hunts and achievements.

[b]Botanicula[/b] is definitely a well-designed game that was created with love and care.  I recommend that any point-and-click, adventure-puzzle gamer considering trying it.  Its charm will cater to fans of the genre both young and old.

I'm a big fan of Amanita Design's point and click adventures.  Here are some of the things you have to look forward to in Botanicula:
[list]
[*]Atypical art
[*]Cute critters
[*]Soothing soundtrack
[/list]

This is a [i]relaxing[/i] game.  Sometimes, when I'm winding down in the evening, I'm not looking for a game that will cause my heart rate to ratchet.  I want to play something that let's me escape the stresses and pressures of my day.  Botanicula is that game. There's a real sense of wonder as you explore the scenes throughout the world.  If I had any complaints it would be that my time in the world of Botanicula was too short.  With just 6 chapters to work through it doesn't take long to finish the game.  You'll receive a score at the end showing how many of the critters you managed to interact with.  While it might compel you to play through a second time, I find that puzzles games tend to be one and done experiences.

16309622.review:
Después de Samorost 2 y Machinarium se esperaba con impaciencia este tercer juego largo de Amanita Design llamado Botanicula, pero el resultado no está a la altura de lo esperado, por lo menos como juego. Dejad que me explique…

Botanicula se trata de una aventura con la misma concepción que los dos juegos antes mencionados: un point-and-click apoyado en la estética particular y atractiva que nos ofrece siempre el estudio checo. Pero aunque este apartado visual es su mayor baza, el conjunto es demasiado simple y lineal, y la dificultad muy baja (el mayor reto consiste en encontrar todos los logros escondidos, pero no hacerlo no influye para nada en el desarrollo del juego).

La temática mezcla el ecologismo y la típica lucha del bien contra el mal, pero salvo por los entornos orgánicos y la originalidad en el diseño de las criaturas (que sí se puede disfrutar) el juego es aburrido. No se conecta con los protagonistas, los puzzles son sencillos en exceso, la duración corta, y la batalla final bastante decepcionante.

¿Lo recomendaría? Sí y no. No es una buena opción como juego, pero la personalidad que destilan todos los diseños de Amanita Design y los guiños a otros de sus juegos siempre merecen la pena. Además es una forma de conseguir que sigan ofreciéndonos sus creaciones. Lo que sí estoy bastante seguro es de que no lo volvería a jugar… para eso prefiero Machinarium o esperar al próximo Samorost 3.
